column5: `The name...is written in the genitive case
column6: the word corpus being understood at the beginning of the inscription.''

column3: `The genitive case is so stereotyped
column4: that the writers cannot accomodate themselves to the nominative which the construction requires.  Thus we get an inscription such as that at  Llaniltern
column5: Glamorgan
column6: where we read VENDUMAGLI HIC IACIT.  In fact
column7: HIC IACIT can hardly be translated literally
column8: `here lies''
column9: at all; rather should we render it
column10: as on certain ancient Scottish tombstones
column11: THIS IS THE LAIR of So-and-so.''

column2: in Anon/1933
column4: `First
column5: the parentage of the person commemorated is not recorded.  Such an omission presumably indicates that he was in his time a person of such importance that his name alone was enough to establish the ownership of the monument.  It is also possible that he was an ecclesiastic
column6: who
column7: so to speak
column8: had renounced his earthly parentage and become a son of the Church.  In the Irish Annals the omission of the parentage
column9: in referring to ecclesiastics
column10: though not invariable
column11: is the rule; but it is unusual in referring to laymen...Thirdly
column12: as so often
column13: we are confronted by the grammatical anomaly of constructing the genitive _Vendumagli_ with the verb _hic iacit_.  We may construe `The stone of Vendumaglos
column14: here he lies'' or treating _hic-iacit_ as a sort of substantive
column15: `The `here-lieth'' of Vendumaglos.''   These expedients
column16: however
column17: are neither satisfactory nor necessary.  The use of the genitive is mere tradition
column18: coming down from the earliest days of monumental epigraphy in these islands.  The _stone_ was not `Vendumaglos'' : it was the stone `of-Vendumaglos
column19: '' and was soecified as such.  Before long
column20: the external case-endings dropped out in pronounciation
column21: and no difference was felt between the nominative and the genitive: compare modern Welsh
column22: where the distinction is expressed by nothing more than the relative position of the substantives.  Writers had a tradition that there ought to be an _i_ at the end of the word
column23: which was not pronounced; they expressed this by writing it horizontally.  Most likely
column24: at the comparatively late date when the engraver of this stone wrote `Venduumagli''
column25: with the horizontal _i_ (probably not less than 300--400 years after the departure of the Romans)
column26: he did not realize that he was writing a genitive at all.  VENDVMAGL{I} was simply the conventional way of writing the name
column27: and it represented a word which served for the nominative as well as the genitive
column28: as the discriminating case-endings had ceased to be pronounced.''"|0|rcaps||"Westwood/1879
column30: `The inscription itself is 2 feet long and 1 foot wide
column31: formed of two lines of rudely-shaped letters. It is to be read---

column1: `...the letters are large and coarsely cut
column2: varying from 3 to 4 inches in height
column3: and exhibit a curious mixture of capital
column4: uncial
column5: minuscule
column6: and even cursive writing; the V
column7: N
column8: A
column9: I
column10: and C being capitals
column11: the E and M uncials; the D
column12: L
column13: and H minuscules; and the G and T cursives.'' (See also Westwood/1871

column3: `The process of supersession of the capitals by the minuscular script can be traced in some inscriptions which give us a mixed form of writing.  An excellent example is the Llaniltern inscription...This also illustrates the horizontal ``I'''' of the genitive termination.''

column2: in Anon/1933
column4: `Secondly
column5: the inscription is palaeographically important.  It stands on the border-line between the earlier inscriptions in Roman capitals and the later inscriptions in minuscules: the two forms of the alphabet are mixed up together to a degree hardly to be paralleled elsewhere is Wales.''

column3: `The inscription is... in rather broad lines
column4: semicircular in section.  It is in...mixed capitals and half-uncials''.

column3: `Mixed Roman capitals (A
column4: C
column5: I
column6: N
column7: V)
column8: and half-uncials (D
column9: E
column10: G
column11: L
column12: M
column13: T)
column14: deeply picked in good style
column15: with horizontal final -I. Some of the letters have `clubbed'' serifs in the manner of the manuscript hand. The A''s have the angular cross-bar. The form of the M is unusual (but cf. Nos. 124

column2: 38: `The letters combine Roman capitals with half-uncials (the latter being E
column3: D
column4: M
column5: G
column6: L
column7: H
column8: T)
column9: and also a horizontal terminal I at the end of the first line. The A-s both have an angular cross-bar as in No. 848
column10: and the abnormal form of M can be paralleled (probably but not decisively) on two other inscriptions of roughly the same period
column11: viz. E.C.M. W. 124
column12: 287 (cf also No. 984). Almost all the letters have expanded terminals.''"|LILTE/1/1

column3: is uncertain about the existence of an ogham inscription on this stone. He notes

He suggests this destruction was contemporary with the addition of the cross. Assessing the legibility of the ''inscription'' Macalister concludes that ''the marks are so faint that it is possible to read almost anything into them''. He then provides a reading of his own.

column3: `The inscription is pocked upon the sinister angle of the southern face
column4: and on the whole is in fair condition except at the beginning
column5: where there are fractures. Brash read it as _Anm Otunilocid maqi Alott_. But his initial AN is made up of natural rugosities on the surface. At first I was inclined to reject the M also; to me it looked like a mere fissure
column6: like another which runs through U2. It was tempting to make a Q out of the initial OT thus giving a familair name QUNILOCI. The final D
column7: however
column8: would be intractable
column9: and the suggested treatment of OT was evidently impossible. The notches of the O are rather widely spaced
column10: but not sufficiently so to compel us to adopt an improbable resolution of the letters into AA. On second thoughts I reinstated the M in my notes. I noticed further that the T is not confined to the H-surface: its proximal ends run below the vowels which flank it
column11: and I decided that it must be intended for {GW}. Inserting a final O which Brash missed...It would not accord with ordinary Celtic syntax to take MO{GW}UNI as a genitive depending on a following nominative LOCID
column12: whatever meaning we might suppose that word to possess. MO{GW}UNILOCID is a long and clumsy name
column13: but not more so than ANAULAMATTIAS
column14: which we have already encountered at Roovesmoore'. |f|vind|1|S|arris|inc|undecorated||pocked|Macalister/1945
column16: `pocked'.|1|goide||0|ogham|||DROUK/1/1

column1: The inscription is in half-uncial. The initial OR has a contraction mark over it
column2: as does the following DO. Both these contraction marks have bifid terminals. The ascender of the D bends to the left over the bow
column3: and has a short vertical stroke at its end. The R''s are capitalis-like; the 1st and 3rd A''s are in the `OC'' form
column4: and the 2nd and 3rd A''s have accents over them; the E is closed."|CLMAC/108/1

column1: `Brash''s reading ALADQ M[AQI] N[O]CATT is apparently due to Windele : in extenuation for its inaccuracy it may be borne in mind that it was made under difficulties
column2: as the stone was still built into the souterrain.  Without any desire to criticize it too harshly
column3: it is well to assure the reader that there is not---and so far as can be judged from any evidence revealed by a most careful scrutiny of the surface---never was
column4: any marking upon any part of the monument that could possibly be read into NOCATT.  The A of ALADQ is likewise quite unjustifiable.  The two O''s
column5: each of which had one admittedly faint notch
column6: have been read as A''s ; the first I
column7: which aadmittedly has rather long scores
column8: trepassing unduly upon the H-surface
column9: has been turned into Q; and the N has been inverted
column10: likewise turning it into Q.  (Even more experienced Oghamists have made similar mistakes amid the manifold discomforts of a souterrain).''

column3: `The stone would have to be dug up for verification of the part now hidden in the ground. - The middle of what can be read today is hardly conceivable; whether there was a second vowel notch below the M cannot be regarded as certain at all. As against O''Kelly''s statement

column5: part of the angle having broken between this and the D; but cp. [sic.] Macalister''s photograph in CIIC 1
column7: where only one vowel notch is marked by whitening.

column1: ... The Ogham inscription is on the left angle of one of the faces
column2: commencing 12 inches from the present ground-level
column3: occupying 5 feet 3 inches of the angle
column4: and finishing within 1 foot 3 inches of the top.

column1: `The first score of the first letter is faint.  In the third character there is some trace of a sixth score
column2: which I believe to be but a fray in the stone.  My copy agress with Mr. Jones''s in the first nine letters.  To the tenth he gives the value of H.  It is true that the part of this score below the line is worn
column3: and almost indiscernable; but taking the five previous letters into combination
column4: it is quite evident that the whole formed the Proper name
column5: SAGROM. The eleveneth
column6: to which he also gives the value of H
column7: is undeniably an M
column8: the score crossing the line or angle.  This
column9: with the three following letters
column10: form the word MAQI.  The fifteenth character is an M
column11: the lower half of which is defaced.  That such is its value there can be no doubt
column12: as the following four letters
column13: with it
column14: form a word so remarkable
column15: and so often found in these inscriptions
column16: the word MUCOI. ...''

column3: `It was growing dark
column4: so that we could not do much then
column5: but we could see at once that Dr Ferguson was right in reading Netta against Brash
column6: who read Neqa.''

column3: `The accompanying figure is copied from the illustration of the stone given by the Rev. H. L. Jones in his account of it published in the Archaeologia Cambrensis
column5: p. 314. This figure was made after repeated examinations of the stone by Mr. Jones
column6: and my own sketch of the stone and its Oghams agrees with that of Mr. Jones. There are
column7: however
column8: several difficulties in deciphering these Oghams which led Mr. Jones to defer attempting a reading of them. The late Mr. R. R. Brash
column9: M.R.I.A.
column10: visited the stone in 1870
column11: and published a memoir on it in Arch. Camb.
column13: p. 24. He considers that the difficulty pointed out by Mr. Jones
column14: arising from the prolongation of some of the upper and crossing consonants to an angular projection on the eastern side of the stone
column15: giving some countenance to the idea of a second line of inscription
column16: does not in reality exist
column17: and that there is no second line of inscription intended ; indeed
column18: had a continuation of the main line of Oghams been required
column19: it would as usual have been carried on to the north-west or right-hand angle of the stone. The Oghams occupy 5 feet 3 inches of the north-east angle ...

column2: vol. xi. p. 48) reads the Oghams as NETTASACHROHOCOUDOCOEFFECI
column3: i. e. `Netta Sagro hoc or Sagromoc oudoco effeci
column4: '' there having been a Bishop Oudoc of Llandaff in the seventh century ; which reading is controverted by Mr. Brash (loc. cit. supra) at great length.
and see Arch. Camb.
column6: p. 92) Dr. Ferguson partly admits the incorrectness of his reading
column7: especially as regards the Oudoc part of the inscription as pointed out by Mr. Brash
column8: but adduces other peculiarities in support of other portions of his reading. To these again Mr. Brash replied in Arch. Camb.
column12: especially insisting on the prefix Nec instead of Netta.

column3: pp. 76
column6: and 1874
column7: p. 90) adopts the reading of the Oghams-

column3: `Westwood made a hopeless attempt to reproduce it all in his plate 54 and Mr Allen [RomillyAllen/1896?] on his part fails to indicate any of the vowels as doubtful
column4: though several seemed to me to be so
column5: when I saw the stone long ago''.

column3: `I read the Bridell stone NETTASAGRI MAQI MUCOE (sic) BRICI.  I could find only four scores in the last vowel of the third word: there ought to have been five.  The last word is certainly BRICI
column4: not BRECI.  It might have indeed have been BRIACI
column5: as there is a fracture on the edge that would contain an A notch
column6: but I incline to the reading given above.''

column3: `The angle is broken after the first R.  Only the first three scores of the following I are clear
column4: but the other two
column5: though faint
column6: are traceable
column7: and the letter should not have been read U
column8: as in previous decipherments.  The third word is
column9: I think

column1: `With the exception of the simply-formed I
column2: C
column3: R (in the first line only)
column4: O and F
column5: which are Roman capitals (and even of these
column6: the lower oblique right-hand stroke of the R not carried down to the line
column7: and the upper cross-stroke of the F forming an angle at its origin with the top of the upright stroke
column8: indicate an approach to the minuscule forms of these two letters)
column9: the whole of the inscription is in that curious mixture of minuscule and uncial letters transformed into capitals which became general soon after the departure of the Romans
column10: and which is found in all the oldest inscriptions and manuscripts both in Great Britain and Ireland. The conjoined et (&) in the first line and cx in the sixth line are especially interesting from their agreement with such ancient documents ; the a like two C''s conjoined together
column11: the b slightly variable in form and sometimes scarcely distinguishable from the g
column12: the best formed one being in the fourth line ; the e like a c
column13: with a central cross bar free at its extremity ; the F almost F-shaped
column14: and not carried below the line ; the g especially remarkable
column15: particularly in the first line
column16: where it is reduced in size from the proximity of the foot of the cross ; the l formed like a L
column17: with the angle rounded off and the top of the first stroke inclined to the left
column18: although in the fifth line it almost looks like a c ; the m invariably m-shaped ; the n either like a capital N but with the oblique stroke reversed
column19: or like a H ; the p P-shaped
column20: and not carried below the line ; the R either R-shaped or like a cursive n
column21: with the second stroke carried down obliquely nearly to the bottom of the line ; the s f-shaped
column22: but not carried above the line ; the t like a c with a tranverse bar at the top
column23: and the u invariably u-shaped. All these peculiarities indicate the occurrence of a period between the departure of the Romans and the time when this stone was sculptured. But I think
column24: from a comparison of this inscription with other early monuments
column25: both lapidary and manuscript
column27: Wales
column29: that we cannot err in affixing to it the date given above. (J. 0. W.

column3: `The documents copied into the Book of Llandaff show that one of the normal forms of signature used by the kings of Morgannwg as witnesses to grants was: A rex filius B.  A less usual variant was A rex B filius
column4: and in this particular source it appears only in documents purporting to be earlier than 900.  The same forms of the royal title occur in the text of the documents.  The spelling of the names on the Carew cross may be compared with those of witnesses in the same series of grants
column5: but a closer parallel to the first is to be found in the pedigrees in Harley 3859
column6: a twelfth century copy of a tenth century MS.''"|0|rbook||"Westwood/1879

column1: `It is remarkable that a not quite correct copy of this inscription has been found in Ireland on R block of sandstone at Fethard Castle
column2: belonging to the Carew family ; for a rubbing of which
column3: forwarded to me in 1863

column5: and reads--

column1: `the lower ends of the terminal x being curved up to the left
column2: the outer one uniting to the lower limb of the left-hand stroke like a 8.''

column3: `I had seen the Carew cross years ago in a regular Dimetian deluge of rain...Huebner gives a reading of mine...but I find I was wrong...Westwood''s reading...is
column4: if anything
column5: still more incorrect...There are several marks and points among the letters of the reading which I am inclined to regard as meaningless and as forming probably no part of the original.  Where I went astray chiefly was not in percieving
column6: that in the third character of the third line and the fourth of the second line mean one and the same letter
column7: namely
column8: an R
column9: with appearance of a P''
column10: excepting that the '' is joined to the rest of the letter.  So I read now _Margiteut Recett_
column11: followed by a biggish F
column12: some abbrevation representing probably _Fecit_.  The inscription stands accordingly thus:---

column1: Possibly one should read _Margiteut Recet g F..._ The former would make _Margiteut Recett fecit_
column2: or ``Meredyd of Rheged made it.'''' ''

column3: `We could see no reason for reading _n_ instead of _u_ in _Margiteut_; but he suggested that at the end one should read F X. for _fecit crucem_; and I should be inclined to do so
column4: but I should be glad to be assured that _x_ ever occurs in that capacity.''

column3: `The inscription is in badly drawn letters

column1: `In the accompanying diagram the letters of the three words are shaded differently

column5: which I had never been able to trace to my own satisfaction till then.  The scribe must have been given a model on a writing tablet set out thus:

column1: `Then by some mental confusion he mistook the EUT for an ET which he ought to have written
column2: and proceeded to write the RE following.  This filled his second line
column3: and then he discovered that he had left out ET.  He added it underneath
column4: spelling it with double T
column5: either from mere illiteracy or under the influence of the EUT written first above.  The last three letters he filled in where he could
column6: the C in the blank before the ETT
column7: the EN in the blank after it.  The N in the model must have been composed of two minims
column8: concave in opposite senses [thus
column9: )( ] ; and the scribe brought them into contact back to back

column11: adding

DERIV|1|1|f|t|some|Macalister/1945, 199--200, `The inscription is difficult to make out, at least at the beginning. The first scores are cut upon a thickening of the angle, which stands out above the adjacent face like a raised margin. There is here an S, followed by a rather ghostly indication of the B-half of an M. But we are not to think of an initial ANM, for there was certainly no fifth score to the S. A space of 4 1/2 inches follows the S, containing nothing but the possible M just mentioned: the H-surface is flaked away, and any letters which may have been there have gone, along with the associated vowels. This space would contain about 9 scores, for the following letters BNAG, which are fairly clear, occupy the same space of 4 1/2 inches. The G tends to a backward slope, as does the M which follows it: there is no trace of any vowel between the G and the M. This M is, no doubt, the initial of MAQI or perhaps MAQQI - there is just room for a lost Q before the Q of which traces are extant. The I of this word is on the shoulder of the stone. On the sinister angle is ERICIA, all rather faint: the H-halves of R12 are broken away, and the C is chipped to evanescence'. |f|vuad|1|inc|arris|beside cross|undivided|OSullivan/etal/1996, 242, `The inscription is...along two angles and across its top'.|incised||0|goide||0|ogham|||DERIV/1/1

column3: `on the two angles of the front face of the stone are several Ogham characters. Those on the left angle are as follow :--- [figure]

column1: `They are situate on the top of the stone
column2: where there is a considerable fracture or flake off at the angle
column3: consequently the inscription is imperfect. The diagonal direction of some of the scores of the first two characters have been remarked on
column4: but there is nothing peculiar in it beyond some freak or inadvertence in the engraving
column5: as I have seen them similarly marked on other monuments. The second inscription on the right angle is as follows :---     [figure]

column1: `H Q D  A H C D NG G O A
`From the long spaces between several of the characters it is quite evident that this inscription is imperfect; that several of the letters have been obliterated
column2: principally vowels
column3: which being usually small circular or oval dots on the angle are generally the first to be defaced either by violence or weather. From the skeleton of the Ogham which remains
column4: it is
column5: however
column6: quite evident that this is not a bilingual inscription
column7: as any filling-up of the missing letters could not produce the equivalent of the Roman inscription. It is also worthy of remark in this
column8: as in all similar cases
column9: that the inscriptions are always reverse
column10: the Roman reading from top to bottom
column11: the Ogham from bottom to top. It is therefore evident that they are by different hands and of different dates. To my mind
column12: the evidence of this worn and mutilated Ogham pillar-stone is that it was appropriated as the monument of a Romanised Briton after having long performed a similar office for some invading Gaedhal.''

column3: `But the most singular circumstance is
column4: that in addition to the Roman inscription there is one of well defined Ogham characters.  It has not
column5: however (as far as ascertained)
column6: been translated.''

column3: `In the small figure and description of this stone which I published in the Archaeologia Cambrensis
column6: I directed attention to the small incised strokes in groups along the two edges of the front of the stone
column7: those on the left side near the top being three parallel
column8: three radiating
column9: [2] and three radiating
column10: and the groups on the right angle from the top having respectively 2
column15: and 5 strokes. These I had no hesitation in regarding as Oghams. A more careful examination which I subsequently made of the stone
column16: verified by additional rubbings
column17: proved that I had overlooked some strokes
column18: as seen in the result of this examination given in Pl. XII ; although
column19: from the evanescent character of many of the strokes by time and ill-usage
column20: it is possible that I have still overlooked some of these marks; indeed
column21: Mr. R. R. Brash
column22: in an article `On the Ogham inscribed Stones of Wales'' (Arch. Cambr. 1869
column24: thus describes and figures these Oghams :---  [Here Westwood quotes Brash given above] ...

column1: `Mr. Rhys (`The Early Inscribed Stones of Wales
column2: '' p. 8). speaking of this stone
column3: adopts a very different and ingenious reading of the Oghams :---`The Celtic characters are very hard to read
column4: owing to their having been extensively worn off. With great deference to archaeologists
column5: I venture to suggest that the following letters are to be traced on the stone : Pompei...oral...smeq . ll . n. The first part of this would be Pompei Carantoral
column6: and the termination al would be our adjectival _-ol_ or _awl_
column7: rendering the Latin _ius_ of Carantorius. Here a character something like the Eisteddfodic  [fig /|\] was extemporised to represent _p_
column8: and when the scribe
column9: if we may so term him
column10: came to make _m_
column11: that was done by making a long stroke across the angle of the stone as usual
column12: but instead of making /|\ for _p_ in this instance
column13: he left out the first line of it and placed the other two lines to lean against the _m_
column14: thus forming a conjoint character for _mp_ which greatly puzzled me.''

column1: `[2] The three radiating lines have much puzzled subsequent writers. Mr. Wendele (Arch. Camb. 1846
column2: p. 413) compared them to the _bird''s-claw Ogham_ of Killarney
column3: whilst the Rev. John Williams (ibid. p.415)
column4: with reference to the supposed Bardic alphabet
column5: gives a legend of Einigan Gawr (the giant) and his three pillars of light
column6: adding
column7: `The Bardic symbol is formed of three radiating lines [fig]
column8: which it is said are intended to represent the three diverging rays of light which Einigan saw
column9: and it is remarkable that these three lines contain all the elements of the Bardic alphabet
column10: as there is not a single letter in it that is not formed of some of these lines. Now are those scores on the left angle of the Kenfegge stone
column11: Glamorganshire. the last and most genuine home of Bardo-Druidism
column12: anything more than representations of the Bardic symbol? ... If these arrow-heads had been alone on the stone I should have considered them mo"|KENFG/1/1

column4: in Anon/1928
column5: 374--375: `The Roman inscription
column6: PVMPEIVS CARANTORIVS
column7: has been known for many years; it was one of the first ancient inscriptions of Wales to attract attention
column8: and not a few wild attempts at interpretating it have been published.  It simply contains two names; the Roman name POMPEIUS
column9: spelt with a _u_ instead of an _o_
column10: and another name
column11: which later appears in the form _Cerentirus_ in the _Book of Llan Dav_---incidentally indicating by the vowel-changes that the name was accented on the penultimate syllable.

column1: `It may be questioned whether in PVMPEIVS CARANTORIVS we have the epitaph of one person or two.  Two names in the nominative
column2: unconnected by any indication of relationship
column3: meet us again at Llanddewi Brefi
column4: in the inscription DALLVS DUMELVS.  At Llangwarren
column5: Pembrokeshire
column6: there are two names similarly independent of one another
column7: TEGERNACI DOBAGNI; and here again
column8: one of those names is echoed in the associated Ogham
column9: but not the other.  The lettering on the Langwarren stone seems to indicate that the two names were cut by different hands
column10: and presumably at different times
column11: pointing to the conclusion that in that case two persons
column12: perhaps two brothers
column13: are commemorated.  But neither the Llandewi Brefi nor the Kenfig inscriptions show any such want of uniformity in the lettering.  The question may be left unanswered.''

column3: `That these two names in the nominative case represent two persons is suggested by the rendering of one of them in the Ogham''.
`While the Roman name Pumpeius (for Pompeius) is probably rendered in the Ogams by an early Irish equivalent such as Popias
column4: there seems to be no correlation in the remainder of the two inscriptions.''"|0|rcaps||"Anon/1869
column6: `According to the writer in Lewis''s _Topographical Dictionary_ the inscription is POMPEIVS CARANTORIVS
column7: but this is an error
column8: for the name is PVMPEIVS; and although Bishop Gibson
column9: in _Camden_
column10: considers it a genuine Welsh inscription
column11: it is simply a Roman inscription
column12: though the person whose name is commemorated may have been a Romanised Briton.''

column2: 19--20: `Roman characters
column3: PVMPEIVS CARANTORIVS; the only doubt being as to whether the second and third letters of the top line
column4: which are conjoined
column5: should be VM or VN. I prefer the former reading
column6: because if read VN the N would be reversed
column7: whereas it is of the proper form in the second line ; whilst the transformation of the second stroke of the V into the first stroke of a conjoined M is of common occurrence. The letters were also read as VM in Camden
column8: as mentioned below...The Welsh Britans (as the Right Reverend the Bishop of Landaff who sent me the copy [of this inscription] informed me)
column9: '' says Camden
column10: `by adding and changing some letters thus read and make this interpretatio : _Pim bis an ear Antopius_ [given in Gough''s Camden _Purnpbus ear a''n lopius_]
column11: i.e. The five fingers of friends or neighbours killed us.'' Holland''s Camden

column1: ` ...As for the word Pumpeius for Pompeius
column2: we have already observed (Lhwyd
column3: Arch. Britan. vol. i. p. 17
column4: col. 2) that in old inscriptions the letter V is frequently used for O [Gibson''s Camden ii

column3: `That is to say
column4: Pumpeius (more usually Pompeius) Carantorius. The first letters
column5: P and C
column6: have been considerably damaged
column7: probably by boys throwing stones at the old monument
column8: for it stands unprotected by the
column9: road-side. The VN seem to form a conjoint character for VM
column10: though they can hardly be said to be completely joined
column11: but no more are the two limbs of the V; otherwise we should have to read V and {N} (or N reversed). The P has a rather small top: the E is of the rounded minuscule kind
column12: and the S in both instances is well developed somewhat below the line of the other letters. The first A shows a bulging out at the ends of the horizontal bar
column13: while the other A is more regular and somewhat broader at the top. The N is rather straggling and carelessly formed
column14: while the tail of the H in both instances tends to be horizontal. Lastly
column15: the O is circular
column16: and
column17: as frequently happens
column18: it is rather smaller than the other letters.''

column3: The VM in the first name is ligatured
column4: and might pardonably be misread VN.''

column3: `Roman capitals
column4: picked and partly deepened by cutting
column5: with half-uncial E and one ligature. The R''s have the open bow and short
column6: nearly horizontal tail. The S''s are elongated.''

column3: `The Latin inscription set in two lines down the length of the face reads PVMPEIVS / CARANTORIVS
column4: formed of fairly regular hut debased Roman capitals with a single ligature; the E is half-uncial
column5: the S-s elongated
column6: and both R-s have an open loop with short tail. These features indicate a mid-6th- century date.''"|KENFG/1/2

column2: 137-138: `With regard to the inscription itself I take it that this began on an angle of the lost back surface
column3: there giving the owner's name: that it then passed to the surviving sinister angle (supposing the stone to be set up with the cross _downward_) reading upward
column4: and concluded on the surviving dexter angle
column5: reading downward... In the second MAQI only I1 remains of the final letter
column6: the rest being broken away. In the dexter angle of the O is a complete vowel
column7: and it may have been preceded by a letter of the H-group (the H-surface is here broken): not of the B group
column8: of which some relics would have survived. This absolutely rules out the restoration _Loggodika_ suggested in _Epigraphy_ [Macalister/1897
column9: 26]. The letter after the O remains to assure us of this
column10: and to shut out alternative readings GD or LG. The last vowel is fractured: it certainly had one notch
column11: though two are conceivable. The scores which lie on the B-surfaces of these angles are abruptly cut short
column12: by the splitting away of the inscribed surface from the original pillar'. |f|mix|3|n/a|arris|beside cross|undivided||inc||1|goide||n|ogham|||AGLIS/1/1

column1: The inscription is in half-uncial. Some of the letters exhibit bifid terminals. The initial O has a contraction mark over it and both taper downwards to a point; the D has an ascender bending to the left over a heart-shaped open-bow; the E is three-pronged with an elongated middle stroke; the A is open-bowed with a flat top and is exactly paralleled by the A''s found at CRACH/1; the R''s are majuscule and the second has a horizontal cross-stroke."|CLMAC/55/1

column4: 72: `The 5th and 8th letters have been damaged.  The 5th is probably a cramped _C_

column6: of which only the first and fourth are plain; their spacing

column9: surface traces suggest the two notches of _O_. Analogy with the other Welsh Ogham stones requires a genitive termination
column10: and it cannot be the commonest such termination _I_ (five notches) or _AS_ (a notch and four rightward grooves).  This confirms _O_
column11: which occurs as the genitive termination of Goidelic nouns whose nominative ends in _-is_ or _-us_.  The inscription thus reads: `(Stone) of Taricoris (or -us)'.  _Tar-_ is a common constituent of Celtic personal names
column12: but this example seems to be elsewhere unattested.'|ABHYD/1/2

column1: This inscription is desolate. As against Macalister''s reading

column4: of his `ACTO'' only the last vowel notch can be made probable. In the middle
column5: it is not easy to verify Macalister''s MAQ; at least
column6: the distance between the M score and what would have to be regarded as the A dot would be extremely short; the same holds true for the first Q score (cp. figs. 7 and 3). In the upper third of the inscription
column7: Macalister''s G cannot be verified; there seems to be just one M score. - There is no indication whatsoever in favour of Macalister''s supposition that the peculiar shape of the stone might be due to a `MAQI MUCOI'' formula having been intentionally destroyed''.

column2: 76--77: `The inscription on its face has apparently been fashioned by an illiterate artificer
column3: copying by rote from a wooden model cut for his guidance
column4: with no very clear idea what to do with it. The surface of the stone being in his judgement too small to hold the inscription in a continuous line
column5: and the craftsman too inexperienced to use the edge as a stem-line
column6: he divided it into two
column7: indicating the '"join'" by star-like marks.

column2: found commonly in Ogham scribbles in manuscripts
column3: was doubtless used when brief communications were made upon waxed tablets or strips of vellum
column4: to avoid the errors latent in this ambiguous script. Without some such indication of the beginning of the writing
column5: the recipient had no guide as to which was the top of the bottom of the line. The mark appears here; as it is in the middle of the line
column6: not at the end
column7: the model must have been cut
column8: not on a rod
column9: but on a ring of wood: the lapidary did not even understand its function. Such rings of wood were not improbably often suspended from stones which now bear no inscriptions: they would be more easily cut than the stone
column10: and would at least outlast a generation.

column1: The inscription is apparently further complicated by the interspersed long strokes
column2: apparently intended to differentiate the separate letters. These may be quite otiose; or they may be exaggerations of the _last_ score of the preceding letter. The latter is
column3: perhaps
column4: the more probable
column5: as the result of ignoring the long scores gives us the meaningless _obudboldse_ (we must read retroversely from the feather-mark
column6: as otherwise we should be embarrassed by the presence of the carefully-avoided letter H)...there are such endless possibilities of miscut or misplaced scores
column7: that to try to restore what the lapidary was actually commissioned to write is perfectly hopeless''. "|f|ind|2|n/a|broad|inc|undecorated||inc||1|ind|Macalister/1945
column8: 77: 'Including the long scores we get UDEDABO ALTASI which might pass for two rather bizarre names: but there are such endless possibilities of miscut or misplaced scores
column9: that to try to restore what the lapidary was actually commissioned to write is perfectly hopeless'.|n|oghms|||AUTAG/1/1

column2: 24: `All the letters are minuscules of the form to which the term Anglo-Saxon has ordinarily been applied
column3: but which might with equal propriety be termed Irish or British
column4: and which is found on many of the inscribed stones both of Ireland and Wales. The rounded form of the b
column5: the p-like form of the r
column6: the y or rather q-like form of the u
column7: and the F-like form of the very distinct terminal f
column8: [1] are all especial forms of these different minuscule letters. The invocation of the Saviour
column9: indicated by the prefixed +
column10: is by no means common on the monumental stones of Wales
column11: although it occurs twice on the stone of St. Cadfan
column12: and several times on the cross of St. Samson at Llantwit (Plates III and IV).

column3: `Both the CT in the first line and the CE in line 3 are conjoined

column7: but it would account for the various readings with A at the beginning of this line.  ...The fourth line is the only one which involves any serious uncertainty.  A piece of stone has flaked away from the centre of the line
column8: removing one or more letters
column9: and damaging the last.  The line has been read D[O]S
column10: but the first letter seems to be an undamaged I
column11: without any trace of the loop of a D.  In the photograph it appears to be followed by a bar and second upright as if an H
column12: but the upright is in fact due to flaking. The bar
column13: although it can scarely be felt
column14: compares with that faintly visible between the I and N of the second line
column15: and suggests that this line too began I--N.  All that survives of the last letter of the line is a complete loop
column16: which could be the upper part of either an S
column17: or more probably of a P; the lower part is destroyed.  The reading I[N]P(ace) seems the more probable of the two.''

column5: then a C (originally MUCOI?). Then there follows another gap of 33 cms followed by what might have been an R

column8: i.e.
column9: G. There is little point in attempting to restore the inscription''.

column8: 48--49: `The markings commencing towards the other end of the stone are as follows:--- three short straight strokes extending to the right (T
column9: 3 inches); then four short vowel marks (E
column10: 4 inches); then 5 straight strokes to the right
column11: the first of which is distinctly separated from the last of the preceding group
column12: whilst the fifth is as long and as distinctly marked as the other 4 (Q
column13: 6 1/2 inches); then on the under angle of the stone are two straight strokes to the left (L
column14: 1 1/2 inch)
column15: followed at the distance of nearly 3 inches by two short oval vowel incisions (O
column16: 2 inches)
column17: to which succeed two long oblique strokes extending over both margins of the stone
column18: the junctions at the angle being defaced
column19: but the continuity of the two strokes is clear (G
column20: 3 1/2 inches); these are followed by five straight strokes to the right
column21: which are quite similar to the right side of the preceding stroke (6
column22: 6 inches); then on the angle of the stone
column23: which is here rather flat
column24: are several irregular shallow impressions which are represented confusedly in the different rubbings.  Mr. Robinson considers there are five
column25: these representing the letter T
column26: whilst Mr. Romilly Allen''s sketch gives only one
column27: representing A; and in my grass-rubbing there is a space of 9 inches
column28: with indications of three oval impressions

column2: 185: `Below _Quegte_ a considerable flake of the edge of the stone has been some time or other hammered off the stone; in fact the points at which the stone was struck are to be detected
column3: four or five of them
column4: but the flake has left the further or upper portions of the five scores for the ||||| of _maqui_
column5: remaining
column6: and I have no doubt that one may venture to consider that the whole inscription originally read as follows...I have to remark that the final _e_ is certain
column7: while as to the other _e_ there is some difficulty
column8: as one finds a good sized notch immediately after the _Qu_
column9: while the remaining three depressions are smaller
column10: and possibly not part of the reading at all.  In that case one would have to read _Quagte_ perhaps; but I think the reading _Quegte_ is much more probable.''

column1: Rhys later revisited the stone and revised the above opinions
column2: stating: `I am now very much in favour of _Quagte_
column3: and inclined to regard the three depressions as accidental
column4: and the cause of the inscriber skipping the space taken up by them'' (Rhys/1896

column2: 401: `Between the Q''s there is space for five or six scores
column3: which can have been only vowels or B-scores. The angle is not badly injured as to prevent the survival of possible traces of vowels
column4: but there is nothing of the kind.  Before the first Q are the marks read M A by Rhys (top half of M only).  They are not nearly so definite as the Q and I take them to be illusory. There are other illusory scores on the face to the left of the inscribed angle
column5: and also on the angle to the left of that again. After the second Q there is one vowel notch
column6: followed by a space of 3 1/2'" in which nothing can be found but three little nicks. These are hardly to be taken with the genuine notch to make E.  There is also a sloping scratch
column7: close to and parallel with the following G-scores
column8: not noticed by Rhys: it is equally out of the question to associate this with the G and to make NG out of them.  The final vowel is certainly E
column9: not I''."|BRAW1/1/1

column5: 49--50: `... and is marked with scorings extending for 32 inches along the angle towards the farmyard.  These scorings
column6: commencing from the bottom
column7: are as follows
column8: as shown in the various rubbings and drawings ... First
column9: a group of five straight stokes to the left (N)
column10: occupying 5 inches  ; then an apparently blank space of seven inches
column11: in which are several irregular impressions which can scarcely be intended for letters
column12: so that the continuity of the writing seems to be doubtful in this part of the stone.  Above this space is another group of five strokes to the left (N)
column13: occupying 4 1/2 inches.  Then follows another space of 5 inches
column14: in which are three or four uncertain equal sized impressions (U or E)
column15: of which the lowest is the largest.  Then follow two long oblique strokes extended to the right
column16: the first forked at its right end
column17: with a third more indistinct line
column18: if indeed it be more than a dot (GO or NG).  These strokes occupy 3 inches
column19: and are succeeded by three short lines to the left (F
column20: 3 inches)
column21: followed by a space of 2 inches
column22: in which is a dot (A)
column23: and ending at top with four stright lines to the right (C
column24: 3 inches).

column1: `The uncertainty in deciphering this  inscription arises chiefly from the blank spaces
column2: which appear destitute of decided letter markings.  Whether this difficulty arises from the abrasion of the surface of the stone in such parts
column3: or from the incompleteness of the inscription itself
column4: is perhaps impossible at the present time to be determined.''

column2: 184--85: ` ... It  may be Vendogne ; I am not sure as to the vowel at the end''.
399: `The last vowel looks at first glance like IIA

column4: however

column8: -gne_ and _-gnea_

column4: 184--85: `I was attracted  by traces of Roman letters near the opposite edge of the face of the stone.  Mr. Harries
column5: noticing this
column6: told me that he had dectected letters there one day as he was passing by on horseback
column7: when the sun was shining right on the stone.  I seemed to find there traces of two lines running parallel with the edge
column8: and in the direction contrary to the Ogam
column9: which is _en regle_.  The outer line seemed to me to end with N --- minus the second upright of the N
column10: which I  could not detect.  If my guess prove well founded
column11: it should be the end of the name _Vendogni_
column12: which probably constituted the whole of the line.  Of the second line I thought I identified IL or LI
column13: which I took to be remains of the word FILI.  But as it was raining torrents during most of the time of my  inspection
column14: I am by no means satisfied that more cannot be made out when the weather is more favourable and the sun is shining. ... [complaints about weather] ... ''

column2: 211: `The other reads VENDOGNI with an echo on the side of the stone
column3: which strangely enough is not in the usual capitals but in minuscules. ... ''.  Macalister goes on to decipher the inscription in the same way as described in Macalister/1945
column5: cited below
column6: concluding: `I put these suggestions forward in no spirit of dogmatism
column7: but in the  hope that someone else will either confirm or disprove them.''

column2: 399: `He [Rhys] describes it as being in two lines ; it is
column3: however
column4: in three.  A sort of cartouche
column5: formed of five short strokes arranged in a curve
column6: confines the inscribed surface at its lower end. ... In line 1 the G is quite clear
column7: as is also the O in line 2
column8: just below it ; the tail of the G and the make a ``figure-of-8
column9: '''' which the reader''s eye should catch first.  The I''s concluding wach line are also clear.  Having fixed G and I in line 1
column10: the N between them can be traced with no great difficulty ; and then
column11: working backwards from the G
column12: we encounter  in turn O
column13: D
column14: N
column15: E
column16: but not the initial U
column17: which has disappeared absolutely.  In line 2
column18: between the O and the I
column19: already fixed
column20: there traces that look like C ; before the O there is an appearance of a much-battered H ; before that again are leics of ILI
column21: but none of F.  The DEGNI which forms line 3
column22: can be traced
column23: but doubtfully
column24: by standing where the light can be seen to strike obliquely on the stone---a midnight visit with a strong electric torch might possibly make the letters more certainly legible.  The porch where the stone lies is small and cramped
column25: and it is difficult to find a suitbale view-point.    Lhuyd found the stone already in use as a footbridge : his drawing gives UENDAGNI as the first line
column27: the asterisks have representing nondescript letters of which the first might by [sic.] SP or R
column28: and the second some form of G.  The third line is ignored.''

column2: 180: `Roman capitals
column3: with half-uncial V. The reading is based on a transcript made by Edward Llwyd in the late 17th century.''"|BRAW3/1/2

column2: 180: `rudely picked''."|1|latin||n|rcaps||"Rhys/1897a
column3: 133--34: ``The first line makes _Briaci fili_
column4: for though a spawl is gone with the upper portion of the RIA
column5: not one of those letters admits of any doubt
column6: unless one should have it that the I was a T.  The next I is rather faint
column7: and the first I of FILI is attached to the lower bar of the F
column8: as in some other instances.  The final I of both lines is horizontal
column9: and the second line ends with G{I}
column10: possibly GL{I} ; but at the last I began to doubt the existence of the L.  Earlier in the line one discerned a V
column11: and imagined one also saw following it am A or an M.  We were
column12: however
column13: unable to guess the second name ; but I  cherish a hope that when the stone has been placed under cover
column14: and the lichen has been succesfully cleaned away
column15: it will be possible to read the whole inscription. ... ''

column2: 210: `I am influenced in this by having traced the same name on the much damaged stone from Rickardstown
column3: now in the porch of Brawdy Church
column4: Pembrokeshire.  I have made a most careful examination of the inscription on the stone
column5: and came to the conclusion that it was to be read:

column2: which I was totally unable to verify.''
402: `Line 1 is certain
column3: notwithstanding some injury by flaking.  The FI is kigatured.  Just in front of the middle B there is a small triangular mark like the head of an A
column4: and about 1 1/2'" before that again there is a short sloping scratch.  These marks are not intentional any more than a well-defined score on the right-hand edge
column5: 5'" above the B
column6: which looks like a Ogham digit
column7: but really is the edge of a spall-matrix.  Equally illusory are some vague marks near the head of the stone
column8: which an imaginative observer might turn into the final vowel of _Briaci_
column9: and the beginning of _Maqi_.  There is actually no Ogham on the stone :  I mention them merely to show that I have not overlooked them.

column1: `Line 2 is much injured.  Beneath the B of line 1 there is a much battered sickle-shaped G.  Then comes a spalled surface
column2: from the top of which the summit of an upright line projects
column3: most likely belonging to an L.  Then comes V
column4: uninjured and certain
column5: and the dexter half of a second V.  The sinister half is reduced to the edge of a flake matrix
column6: within the area of which the outlines of O C can be faintly traced.  Then comes the top of another C
column7: and the final I.  There is a sloping mark
column8: not I think
column9: part of the inscription
column10: but which if prolonged
column11: would turn the second of these C''s into another sickle-shaped G
column12: and as such it is represented in Rhys''s diagram ; but his restoration
column13: [E] V[OLEN]G{I}
column14: is hardly borne out
column15: either by the existing remains or by the blank spaces.  In AC 1896
column17: BRIACI is misprinted BRINACI.  We have already seen the name GLUVOCCI (with one C) at Ystradfellte (345) and we shall meet with BRIACI at Bridell (426).''

column2: 180: `Roman capitals
column3: rudely picked
column4: with half-uncial capital E and F/I conjoined. The final -I''s are horizontal ; the A has an angular cross-bar.''"|BRAW4/1/1

column3: comments on the surviving piece of stone

column2: 13: `The inscription covers the two angles of the southern face. Its beginning is badly damaged by spalling
column3: to all appearance with intention: as at Corrower [CORRO] the destroyer worked on the dexter angle up to the limit of his reach
column4: but he left the sinister angle alone.

column1: A large flake has gone from the B-surface of the injured angle...and nothing now appears but an L
column2: followed by a vowel (apparently E)
column3: and after that the B-halves of two G''s. A smaller
column4: but yet more effective
column5: fracture on the H-surface has abolished the H-halves of the G''s and anything else that there might have been on that side. A battered length of angle follows
column6: and then follows a row of fairly perfect letters
column7: running up to the top...After several examinations of the stone
column8: I have given up all hope of filling
column9: even imperfectly
column10: the long gap after the G. The gap after 1D cannot have contained anything but vowels
column11: of which three notches remain. Having regard to the length of the space
column12: the most likely restoration is IU. The remainder of the inscription is quite clear: the final D is
column13: and always was
column14: the last letter on this side
column15: but I have no suggestion to make as to the meaning of this part on the inscription [sic]''.

BREAY|1|1|f|f|good|Forsyth/1996, 119: `Inscription intact, clear, and well preserved'. |f|vup|2|inc|narrow|beside cross|undivided|Forsyth/1996, 119: `The two lines of ogham occupy almost the full length of the narrow edge of the slab...The longer of the two lines, the right-hand side, consists of twenty-nine letters and starts parallel with the feet of the lion. The shorter side, to the left and comprising nineteen letters, begns a little higher, level with the mouth of the lion, and ends a little lower'. |inc|||ind||1|ogams||Forsyth/1996
column3: `There are five _forfeda_ at Bressay
column4: one of which is repeated. Three of these are paralleled on other Scottish monuments and also in Irish manuscripts
column5: but the other two are unique to Bressay.

column1: Character _Right 4_:...this is probably not a _forfid_ but rather a corrected error in carving...
Character _ Right 20. 21_ : This rabbit-eared character is unique to Bressay. Since it consists of two strokes to the left of the stem previous authorities have taken it as some kind of modified D
column2: presumably the voiced spirant...This seems by far the most likely explanation (and if it is not we can only guess at this character''s value)
column3: but implies a breakdown in the old convention DD for /d/
column4: D for [voiced aspirant] /d/ (presumably the initial D in the following word has the value /d/ because of the practice of avoiding geminate consonant symbols in word-initial position [Harvey 1987]).

column1: Character _Right 28_:...Angled vowels...may indicate long vowels. Whatever its value
column2: we may take it as some form of A
column3: contrasting with the standard A-character occurring  in the previous two words (_10

column2: five undulating strokes sloping backwards across the stem is presumably a vowel
column3: since it occurs between the second and the third of a group of three Ns. As a five-stoke vowel we may take it as some from of I
column4: rather than R. Angled-stroke I...does not occur at Bressay
column5: but since angle-stroke A does
column6: we may have warrant for rejecting /f/ as the value of this character. Though it is really rather different from them
column7: it may be useful to compare instances elsewhere in Scottish oghams of cross-strokes with flaps
column8: e.g. Birsay 1-2 [BIRSY /1
column9: BIRSY/2]
column10: Latheron [LARON]
column11: Lochgoilhead [LOHED/1
column12: LOHED/2]
column13: though most of these face in the opposite direction.

column1: Character _Left 15_: A character consisting of _four_stroke cross-hatching..appears in the late eighth or ninth-century Bern ogham alphabet  and syllabary under a label which has previously been read as RR. Sims-Williams has argued convincingly that instead ths is SS (1992:38--39
column2: fig. 5)
column3: but rather than remove the manuscript key to the Bressay character''s value
column4: he has in fact demonstrated the precedent (with the letters BB and LL) which shows that the _five_-stroke character here...represents RR. Sims-Williams  suggests that monograms for LL and RR were generated by ''late but keen-eared ogamists'' to represent the geminate or long liquids /ll/ and /rr/ (1992: 72). The context of this character at Bressay
column5: after DD and before OA
column6: fits Sims-Williams interpretation
column7: but if the _forfid_ is /rr/
column8: what then is meant by the doubling of the ordinary R character on the other line of text (_right 2/3)_   and _26/7_)? As Macalister points out
column9: though it may be easier to read
column10: this character is not easier to carve
column11: and
column12: since there was ample space for two characters
column13: we can only assume some nuance of phonology/orthography drove its inclusion. The only other instance of this character in practical use is at Burrian [BURIN/1
column14: BURIN/2]. It appears in the Book of Ballymote [No. 64
column15: Calder 1917 Aur. 6085)
column16: but there all the letters are doubled and the device has no phonetic significance.

column1: Character _Left 16_: ...This character is disucssed in the entry on Formaton [see also Sims-Williams 1992:58-60]''.

`The letters are very irregular in size
column4: some being 2 and others as much as 4 1/2 inches in height. They are of a mixed character
column5: showing quite a different style of writing from that of many of the Carmarthenshire stones. Thus the sixth letter of the first line is a miniscule g with a transverse top bar
column6: the SS are f-formed
column7: the H in the second line is an angulated minuscule. The initial T is semi-uncial
column8: with the bottom of the vertical stroke bent to the right. Every E has the middle bar greatly elongated. The terminal T is quite minuscule
column9: with a dash for the top cross stroke. The u of the second line might possibly be read LI conjoined.''

CLMAC|76|1|f|t|some||f|horz|2|n/a|broad|within quadrants|separated|The inscription is in the two upper quadrants.|inc||1|goide||0|rbook||The inscription is in half-uncial. CLMAC|77|1|f|t|some|Macalister/1909, 21, `Parts of three letters remain at the top; it is difficult to decipher these, as the first seems to be an A inverted with respect to the rest'. Macalister then states that his reading can 'only be a guess'.|f|inc|1|n/a|broad|within quadrants|separated|The inscription that remains is in the two upper quadrants. It is uncertain whether the inscription was aligned horizontally, or whether it might have been circular.|inc|||ind||0|rbook||Macalister/1909, 21, argued that the first letter was an inverted A, with the second letter O and the third possibly a D. The script of the inscription is therefore dependent on how we see the A. It could be a capitalis A, but other examples such as those on CLMAC/78 and CLMAC/84, indicate that it is an angular half-uncial A.|CLMAC/77/1
CLMAC|105|1|f|f|good||f|verd|1|n/a|broad|within quadrants|separated|The inscription runs vertically in one line through the two right-hand quadrants.|inc||1|goide||0|rbook||The inscription is in half-uncial with an initial textual cross. CLMAC|78|1|f|f|some|The top of the last two letters on the first line have been lost.|f|horz|2|n/a|broad|mixed|separated|The inscription , as we have it, is in the upper left quadrant, and on the upper arm of the cross.|inc||1|goide||0|rbook||The inscription is in half-uncial. The initial OR has a contraction mark over it; the R is majuscule; the V is particularly open with the right-hand stroke having a curved extension; the 1st A is angular and four-sided and the 2nd angular and three-sided; the second D has a vertical ascender with a finial and an open bow.|CLMAC/78/1
CLMAC|79|1|f|f|good||f|mix|2|n/a|broad|within quadrants|separated||inc||1|goide||0|rbook||The inscription is in half-uncial. The initial OR has a contraction mark over it. The A of the 2nd line is angular and the R minuscule. The CH are conjoined, but not ligatured. The D is open-bowed with an ascender bending leftwards. The E is three-pronged, with the middle stroke not attached to the upright, and the final S's are minuscule.|CLMAC/79/1
CLMAC|80|1|f|f|some|Macalister/1909, 22, `the surface of the stone is much flaked, but this has not seriously interfered with the cross or inscription'.|f|horz|1|n/a|broad|within quadrants|separated||inc||1|name||0|rbook||The inscription is in an angular form of half-uncial, with the bows of the A and D almost lozenge shaped. CLMAC|82|1|f|f|good||f|horz|1|n/a|broad|within quadrants|separated|The inscription is in the two lower quadrants.|inc||1|name||0|rbook||The inscription is in half-uncial. CLMAC|84|1|f|f|good||f|horz|2|n/a|broad|mixed|separated|The first line of the inscription is above the cross, and the second line is within the two upper quadrants.|inc||1|goide||0|rbook||The inscription is in half-uncial. CLMAC|85|1|f|f|good||f|horz|3|n/a|broad|mixed|separated|The inscription is in the upper sinister quadrant, the two lower quadrants, as well as on the shaft of the cross.|inc||1|goide||0|rbook||The inscription is in half-uncial. column3: notes that many earlier authors had not believed that the marks on the left hand edge of the stone were ogham---the first author to correctly discuss them being Brash (Rolt-Brash/1869) who then discussed them more fully in 1871 (Rolt-Brash/1871) at which time he offered a reading for the start of the inscription.  Westwood goes on to note that it was surprising that Brash had missed the oghams near the top of the stone thought by Rhys (Rhys/1874) to represent LLUNI.

column7: but his figure of them in p. 154 by no means corresponds with the true position and form of the marks. These he partially corrected in his article on this stone (Arch. Camb.

column1: `It is surprising that Mr. Brash overlooked the Ogham marks at the top of the stone terminating
column2: or rather commencing
column3: opposite the P at the beginning of the second line. These are added on my plate at the left-hand end of the stone from sketches and rubbings by myself and Mr. Robinson of Cardiff
column4: one of the Secretaries of the Cambrian Arch~ological Association [2]. Prof. Rhys (Arch. Camb.
column6: p. 19) gives these upper marks as equivalent to Lluni
column7: the remains of Trilluni
column8: which occurs as Triluni in the Roman letters.''

column2: 315--316: `The first four letters are quite clear
column3: the P being represented by a simplified form of the I-forfid.  The first three notches of the following I are broken away.  There is only one L
column4: though a fracture on the surface preceding it might be mistaken for a second L.  The first two notches of the following I remain
column5: the other three being quite abraded.  Of the surviving notches
column6: one is oblique and appears to be longer than the ordinary notches
column7: so it might be mistaken for an ordinary M ; it is not however
column8: really longer than the vowel notches in the beginning of the inscription.  After this
column9: nothing is clear but LL..N
column10: followed by three vowel notches
column11: at the top of the stone.  The two L''s are crowded together and certainly would have been taken for an S if we had not the corrective guidance of the Roman TRILINI.  The vowel between the L''s and the N is gone : there is hardly room for U
column12: and it most probably was an O. The top of the stone is broken carrying with it the two final notches of the final I.  If there was ever anything in the Ogham corresponding to the concluding DVNOCATI of the Roman [CRCKH/1/2]
column13: it is altogether broken away : almost the whole back of the stone has become detached over a cleavage-plane
column14: and it is quite possible that the completion of the inscription may thus have been lost.

column1: `Returning now to the space following TURPILI... the edge is almost worn smooth
column2: but on minute examination the following traces can be detected:---
between the TR of the Roman TRILVNI
in line with the R of PVVERI

column1: `3. The first and last scores of a C
column2: in line respectively with the outer tips of the horizontal bars of the E of PVVERI
column3: and with the vertical bar of the same letter.

column2: in line with the second V of PVVERI.  Nothing remains of the R which should follow ; it must have filled up so much of the available space that it would have been impossible to crowd in the five notches of an I.  There is hardly room for more than the one notch of an A.

column1: `These traces are sufficient to enable us to fill in the inscription
column2: as set forth above...''."|CRCKH/1/1

column5: he suggested that the inscription read CALIACI(AS) MAQQI MUCOI... This suggested restoration is not supported by any marks on the stone and even the M score is very doubtful. The second L score appears to have been shortened to avoid the arm of the cross. This suggests that the ogham inscription was carved after the cross though the time lapse may not have been great. Macalister noted some small scores at the bottom of the inscribed angle which appeared to form OBAM. These are probably natural or accidental marks''.

column3: ''In Gaul the rounded E appears on inscriptions in the early sixth century. The forms of the A is derived from uncial and the S from the half-uncial script which was used as a book hand in the 6th century. The stone belongs to the last group but is earlier than that at Llangadwaladr''.

column1: The word _filius_  is all in capitals except for the half-uncial ''S''
column2: and it is followed by an interpunct. The ''E'' which begins the father''s name is rounded and appears to have a vertical stroke joining the three lines on the right. The ''A'' of [a]nima is minuscule and is formed by two strokes
column3: a small ''c'' on the left
column4: and a vertical stroke with left-facing flourish on the right. This word is followed by another interpunct. The ''R'' of the last word is open bowed
column5: the ''Q'' is half-uncial as is the ''S''. The two ''Es'' are rounded
column6: without a middle stroke
column7: but with a vertical stoke to the right."|HENEG/1/1

column5: `The inscription illustrated in the original publication (reproduced here as Fig. 9 with tones reversed) is in four (horizontal?) lines
column6: apparently reading ERECOR / MAGLORI / CVNIIAC / FICIT. The letters are all Roman capitals except for cursive forms of G and L
column7: a feature which together with the proper name elements establishes a strong case for accepting it as an authentic Early Christian inscription of the late 5th century...The third and fourth lines require some elucidation. CVN (or CVNI) is again a common element of personal names
column8: [4] CVNIIAC[I] or CVNIIAC[VS] being acceptable forms. FICIT for fecit is possible though not paralleled
column9: but it is also possible that the form of the stone (which cannot be known) would enable FIC to be read either as HIC or as ligatured FILI
column10: with IAC / IT added at the ends of these two lines. In such a reconstruction the inscription would read ERECOR[I] / MAGLORI / CVNI / HIC IAC / IT or . . . CVNI / FILI / IAC / CIT.

KILMA|1|1|f|t|good|Macalister/1945, 6--7: `A fracture follows the O, large enough to contain two scores or notches, but had they actually been there some trace of them might have remained; for this, enough of the inscribed surface is intact, even in the neighbourhood of the fracture. The proximal ends of the C are spalled away. The antepenultimate letter looks like an S, and Rhys (whose interpretation of the whole inscription I regret that I cannot see my way to accept) takes it as such; but, on close examination, S2 and S3 are seen to form a character resembling a 6, broken at the bottom. This looks like the U-_forfid_, which would give us the word BUBEL or BUABEL. Rhys further adds an A after the L, but the mark thus read is only a fracture; it is placed, not on the edge, but on the B surface, and must, I think be rejected'. |f|vuad|1|inc|arris|n/a|undecorated||incised||1|goide||n|ogham|||KILMA/1/1
KILMA|1|2|f|t|some|Macalister/1945, 6--7, notes a fracture through the ogham following the seventh character, but adds that for the early elements of the inscription 'enough of the inscribed surface is intact, even in the neighbourhood of the fracture'. This cannot be said of its later characters. Macalister  notes that the 'proximal ends of the C are spalled away', and queries Rhys/1907 on the reading of the antepenultimate letter as an S. Macalister suggests rather a U-forfid. The poor legibililty of the majority of this inscription led him to attempt a retroverse reading, resulting in 'nothing..better than Decuns o Micill', which, he suggests,  'is worth recording, if only as a warning that nothing is to be expected from this expedient !'. |f|vuad|1|n/a|arris|n/a|inc||incised||1|goide|||ogham|||KILMA/1/2

Someone noticed this and set himself to correct it, by the rather futile device of suggesting an inversion of the remainder of the inscription'.|KLCOO/1/2
KLCOO|2|1|f|f|poor|Macalister/1949, 125, `the stone is so badly spalled that it is difficult to choose between ambiguities.'|f|horz|1|ind|broad|below cross|undivided|Macalister/1949, 125, `It bears a...Latin cross...and an inscription beneath the foot inverted with respect to it.'|inc||1|name||0|rbook||Macalister/1949, 125, `Wakeman gives a reading EDCU MIC LIE, of which he optimistically says that it `seems to be satisfactory.'  It is, in fact, wrong throughout: but the stone is so badly spalled that it is difficult to choose between ambiguities.  We have: an initial cross; the lower part of a letter that may be c, e, t, or l; d or o; another letter like the first, but so much battered, that the further alternatives, A, b, must be added; another battered letter---the traces suggest g: then idic fairly clear, though the d might concievably be a damaged n or an R. Then comes a blank space, wide enough to hold one letter but never filled in, and the Ae, completing the inscription, and (in spite of the preceding blank) to be attached to whatever word goes before.  The nearest approximation to a restoration attainable by me, is COLGIDICAE, which cannot be called completely satisfying.'|KLCOO/2/1

column3: `This is the only instance I know of _iacet_ on a Romano-British stone ; the usual form is _iacit_.''  [Discussion of names in name table]

column2: 88: `The classical form _iacet_ (instead of _iacit_) is exceptional in Wales...though normal in Gaul.  Elmet (Elfed) was the name of the ancient British Kingdom of corresponding roughly to what is now the West Riding of Yorkshire
column3: whose existence as a separate territorial division in the sub-Roman period is here directly attested... Aliortus
column4: a native of the region
column5: had apparently settled in N. Wales and died there.''"|0|rcaps||"Westwood/1867
column7: `The inscription is entirely cut in Roman capitals of good proportions
column8: although slightly irregular in size.''

column3: `On my former visit [see Rhys/1873] I read it---

column1: but I had grave doubts as to the G
column2: and as I had not duly taken into account the red lead with which the letters had been filled
column3: I thought it right to visit the stone again.  The second character contains all the lines necessary to make a conjoint LH
column4: but there is no lead in the line forming the bottom of the L ; if this is to be taken as a sure indication
column5: the reading is simply H... What I read as G he [Westwood] read as S
column6: but a line at the top of it would make it a good Hiberno-Saxon G
column7: but the said line shows no trace of red lead
column8: and as the G would be out of keeping with the rest of the letters I have no doubt that the right reading is S.  Unfortunately the red lead is at present not to be depended very much upon

column3: `Apparently the artist of the cross did not notice his predecessor''s work till he had completed his task
column4: and. when he did so
column5: cautiously chipped it away
column6: tkaing care not to spoil his own handiwork.  He was obligued to spare the final S
column7: which lay upon the arm of the cross
column8: to avoid spoiling the latter with an unsightly flake.  The work of destruction has not been complete : his carefulness has forced him to leaves tips of scores along the B-surface : an R. and N (possibly)

column10: the second score of the last letter can be followed almost throughtout its length.  Restoring the voewls by the interspaces

column1: `There are a few palaeographic peculiarities in this inscription: the second letter in the first line being a U
column2: not V
column3: and the N reversed in shape {N}
column4: the U indistinct and injured
column5: and the terminal S greatly elongated below the other letters; the word is also here in the nominative case.  In the second line the F and I are conjoined
column6: and the final I placed transversely
column7: as is often the case.  In the third line the g is of the Hiberno-British form
column8: and the N again reversed
column9: whilst the H at the beginning of the last line has the transverse bar very oblique
column10: and the A in jacit (for jacet) much elongated below the other letters. With these exceptions the inscription is in Roman capitals
column11: the letters being generally about 4 inches in height...From the more debased form of the letters I infer that it is somewhat more recent than the gravestone of Clutorix. [LDYSI/1]''

column8: whilst the eighth letter
column9: which is earned much below the line and with a very slight top cross bar
column10: led me on the spot to regard it as a S. Prof. Rhys
column11: however
column12: having subsequently visited the stone
column13: read the first word EVOLENGG{I} (Arch. Camb.
column15: p. 186) ; and having shown me his rubbing
column16: which was much clearer than my own
column17: I must admit that the seventh letter is an injured g
column18: that the eighth fetter is also a g
column19: and that it is followed by a horizontal {I} which I had overlooked. In the accompanying Plate LIII
column20: fig. 5
column21: I have given the name as it appears in the rubbing of Prof. Rhys
column22: except that the terminal letters are made too decided.''

column7: `I have now before me a number of sketches and rubbings made by the Rev. H. L. Jones
column8: Mr. Wakeman of Dublin
column9: and myself
column10: confirmed by an examination of the stone itself. The first letter terminates below in a triangular impression
column11: which leads me to infer that it is a G ; the second is clearly a minuscule e with the horizontal cross-bar extending half an inch beyond the loop ; the third letter resembles H
column12: but it is clearly an N of one of the Hiberno-Saxon forms of that letter ; the fourth letter is a minuscule l
column13: with the bottom of the stroke bent upwards ; the following letters ISI are clear. The next is N
column14: in another of the Hiberno-Saxon forms of the letter common in eighth or ninth century MSS.
column15: followed by |BT~ DS~. The small horizontal lines over the last four letters indicate that two words are here contracted ; the d~s~ I apprehend unquestionably stand for the word deus
column16: and I venture to suggest that the two preceding letters bt~ are the contracted form of the word benedicat or benedicit (the Llanwnnws Stone
column17: Ph. LXVIII. fig. l
column18: giving the clue to the latter word). I therefore read the inscription
column19: `Genlisini benedicit deus.''

column9: 209--10: `The mixed formula shows that this inscription does not belong to the earliest group.  Instead of _Domnici Fili Bravecci
column10: all genitives
column11: `(The Stone) of D. son of B.'' or the alternative _Domnicus Filius Bravecci Iacit_ (or _Hic iacit_)
column12: with the nominative _Domnicus_ as subject of the verb _iacit_
column13: the author has made a blend of the two formulas
column14: beginning with the person''s name in the gentive as in Type I then passing to Type II.  This shows that he lived in a period when the difference between the nominative and genitive cases had been forgotten : he tried to follow the models known to him on other memorial stones
column15: but his Latin was insufficient to sort out the types.  Hence the blend !''

column3: 210-11: `On the lettering I have little to add.  The form of the R in _Bravecci_ is exactly like one I saw in the Douglas Museum
column4: Isle of Man
column5: in a very similar inscription (Knoc of Doonee)...dated by the Museum authorities in the early sixth century.  Another is seen in the Anglesey ETTORIGI...also dated in the sixth century ;  and still another on the _Boduoc_ stone...BRA/VECCI may be read _Brravecci_ or _Branecci_
column6: for -AV- and -AN- are ligatured in inscriptions...the case is  stronger for the reading _Braviccos_
column7: or so it seems to me.  First of all the instances of the ligature AN are very much rarer than those of AV in our inscriptions.  Of the former I found two instances in Westwood''s Pl. 98
column8: 6 on a Caerleon stone : of the latter I counted nine.  Furthermore
column9: where AN are ligatured the second stroke of the N is perpendicular : in the case of ligatured AV the second stroke of the V slopes to the right...In the new inscription this slope is obvious
column10: and so Brenych must be rejected
column11: and we are left with Braveccos
column12: Welsh _Brewych_''

column2: in Fox/etal/1943: `The lettering is pure Latin
column3: of the `vulgar'' sort
column4: with the usual traces of cursive influence
column5: e.g. the ligatured FI and the P-
column6: and also the sickle S.  The P- is the latest feature
column7: but I doubt if later than the fifth century.  The vertical arrangement of the inscription
column8: following Ogham practice
column9: is a Celtic feature.''
