column3: `On the day when I visited the stone with Dr. Owen it was raining so hard that it was very difficult to do it justice
column4: but on my second visit I had a very fair day. Under even the most favourable circumstances the reading is extremely puzzling...This is what I have made of it:

column1: The first lacuna would take four or five notches ; I give the preference to the former
column2: that is the vowel _e_. As to the next
column3: I am puzzled whether to assign it one or two ; that is _a_ or _o_. After the wider gap the scoring seems to yield _aseg_
column4: followed by three scores on the B side which are complete
column5: and followed by two more imperfect ones : I guess the group to have consisted of five scores
column6: making the consonant _n_. Now _gn_ suggests at once the very common ending _-agn-_
column7: in the genitive _-agni_
column8: in Ogam epitaphs ; but besides _-agni_ there also occur _-egni_ and _-igni_. Looking at the stone itself I could hardly decide between four notches or five
column9: but I find that one of Mr. James''s photographs enables me to decide for four
column10: the vowel _e_. There are two mom>e vowel groups of notches to be guessed
column11: and supposing the whole to end with a word in _-egn-_
column12: I have suggested an _i_ to make a genitive _-egni_
column13: at the end. The width of the gap before _asegn_ seems also to demand at least five notches
column14: which would indicate that the first part of the inscription ended also with a genitive in _i_. Whether this would quite fill that gap I am by no means sure ; but I should hardly go beyond two more scores
column15: whether short or long> This would leave us to choose between _Asegni
column16: Osegni
column17: Basegni
column18: Masegni
column19: Dasegni
column20: Lasegni
column21: Gasegni_ : it is useless to guess any further.

column1: `Besides the doubts which enter at the vowel gaps the first vowel and the first consonant make room for another to come in making | ||||////
column2: ef
column4: _ing_
column5: or let us write i[Gw] with the character used by German glottologists for _ng_ : in Ogam the

column1: [Gw] has the symbol of three slanting scores ///. It happens that the first score of the ///// is not very clearly produced towards the left or the H side ; but it is on the B side. One might perhaps regard that as no part of the writing : then there would be nothing left but a notch as part of the initial vowel. However
column2: the notch
column3: if such
column4: will be found also in the case of the second score of the four
column5: ////. In this case the first name would be _I[Gw]issa[Gw]i_. As regards the first consonant
column6: Mr. James wrote to me before I had seen the stone
column7: as follows :_``The photograph marked 1 shows clearly that there are not more than four long strokes above the lowest group of notches. No. 2 seems to suggest only three
column8: but I noticed that there is a faint long stroke below the three next to the notches on the right side of the edge only. It does not show clearly on the left side of the edge.'''' That is so
column9: and Mr. Eyre Evans
column10: without knowing anything about the photographs
column11: on March 31
column13: read the slanting scores as four
column14: and not three
column15: without any hesitation. Dr. Owen and I tried to decide the point
column16: but it was raining so hard that we made no satisfactory progress towards that result
column17: and I felt that it would be necessary to examine the Ogam again
column18: if possible not in thunder
column19: in lightning
column20: or in rain. In October 1910 I got a fairly fine day with no rain
column21: and I examined the four slanting scores as carefully as I could : I came to the conclusion that the first was produced beyond the edge on the left or H side
column22: but it was faint as if the surface of the stone had by some accident been abraded there. So I give up considering the first part of the inscription as i[Gw] : this I do as a matter of reading. If
column23: however
column24: anybody wished to treat the name as I[Gw]essa[Gw]i
column25: I may point out one grave difficulty attaching to it_--namely
column26: that all our Ogam inscriptions show only five or six instances of the guttural nasal [Gw] in all
column27: while this reading would supply two more in one and the same word. So any calculation of the chances would
column29: prove heavily against I[Gw]essa[Gw]i being the right reading.''

column1: `The letter [sic.] in this Llangian stone are about two inches high.  The M is to be noticed as having its first and last strokes slanting like a W turned upside down (M); and in the second M the tops of these two strokes are carried higher than the places of junction of the strokes of the middle V
column2: giving the letter somewhat of the appearence of the _rustic-shaped_ capital M
column3: which is also an indication of very great age in Roman inscriptions
column4: occuring very often in those found at Pompeii.  The L and I in the first word are conjoined
column5: the I not being so tall as the L
column6: and extending below the line;  this conjunction indicates a debased style
column7: and which I have seen carried so far that the L and I were formed thus [L I ligature drawn] (The _i_ at the end of the words is often carried like a _j_
column8: below the line
column9: in early Irish and Anglo-Saxon MSS).  The F and R are also debased in their forms
column10: especially the latter
column11: in which the first stroke extends slightly below the line
column12: the loop is very large
column13: and the bottom right hand stroke almost horizontal.  We have here
column14: therefore
column15: an approach to the debased miniscule R [drawn] as it appears for instance on some of the Llantwit stones...The M and A
column16: too
column17: in the beginning of the word MARTINI are conjoined.  With these exceptions the letters are very good Roman capitals
column18: and I should be inclined to consider the inscription as not later than the fifth century.''  (See also Westwood/1879

column1: `The construction of the genitive with _Hic iacit_ is well established.  It is due to a confusion of two formulae
column2: [_Hic ets lapis_] _Rusticae_ and _Hic iacit Rustica_.  The custom of using the genitive on stones under the influence of the first formula had become so stereotyped
column3: that in defiance of grammar it was continued after the second formula was introduced.  That the latter common formula has not been adopted mechanically on the stone before us
column4: but has been modified by the interpolation of the words _in tumulo_
column5: shows that some thought was given to the composition of the epitaph.''  Macalister then goes on to state that he does not agree with Rhys'' attempt to show the metricality of these inscriptions.

column2: 178: `The extended formula _Hic in tumulo iacit_
column3: like the simple _Hic iacit_
column4: is of Christian-Roman origin. It appears in Italy in the 4th century A.D.
column5: and subsequently comes into vogue
column6: in variant forms
column7: in N. Africa
column8: Gaul
column9: and (more rarely) Spain
column10: in the 5th and 6th centuries.[1] It occurs again in Wales on Nos. 4
column12: and 409. Mention of the age of the dead person is exceptional on a Welsh monument.[2] For in pa(ce) cf. No. 83.

column2: as to which I feel no doubt

column6: I think
column7: no part of the writing; otherwise one would have to read _o_ instead of _a_.  Before the _lica_ we have traces of the final vowel of a previous word
column8: and some distance lower the scores for _l_; but the edge is too much damaged to aloow of anything more being made out.  Even this far exceeded my expectation
column9: and I consider that one reason for my being able to read more this time was
column10: that ivy had overgrown the stone
column11: so that when it was torn off it left the surface clean
column12: at any rate clear of lichen
column13: which is the great obstructor to reading what is written on stones in the open air...it has further interest
column14: that it is so placed that its _a_ is written underneath the moulding in a position where no man in his senses would have ever begun his writing of the Ogams.  So one may be practically certain that the Ogams read upwards on the edge of the altar
column15: as one in any case would expect them to do.''

column10: 408: `The Lunnasting inscription is written in a controlled and measured form of Type II ogham
column11: ogham written on a stem-line with a number of _forfeda_
column12: including a unique _forfid_
column13: and the other ''late'' features  the binding of all letters
column14: and the division of words...The ordinary vowel strokes are long
column15: occupying perhaps three-quarters of the ogham band
column16: and there are no less than five vocalic _forfeda_. All the letters slope as one might expect. Component strokes are neatly parallel and well-spaced. Most bind-strokes are parallel to the stem
column17: but some letters exhibit a `diminuendo'' effect with each stroke shorter than the previous and the bind-stroke sloping down towards the stem
column18: others are parallel except for a final shorter stroke. The bind-strokes mean the inscription is very clear
column19: but in addition the letters are all very generously spaced''.

There are no manuscript  or epigraphic parallels for this character''.

column5: which is probably complete
column6: and begins with _ninomine_ for _in nomine_. The initial blunder arose probably from the inscriber having first made the five perpendiculars of inn and then carelessly joining the two first
column7: so that he made what should have been _in_ into _ni_. There is a mark of contraction over the _di_; the _et_ is a conjoint character
column8: and it is followed by a small [capital-Lambda]
column9: which on being examined with a candle was seen to have a short tag which made it into F.[1] Above it is a mark which I take to indicate that the F stands for FILI : the inscriber would seem to have accidentally omitted that word
column10: so he made it good so far as room and symmetry allowed. Westwood erroneously represents the _et_ as made up of two separate letters
column11: one of which seems to cover the space taken up by the small F. In the last two lines the _s_''es are of the rounded kind
column12: but reversed
column13: and the last of all is adorned with two points. The _r_ in patris is joined to the following _i_; the _n_''s in _santdi anc_ have their first perpendicular prolonged downwards below the level of the second
column14: while the _n_ in _anima_ is more like an h. The spelling _eus_ for _eius_ is probably due to carelessness.

column8: `The S is throughout of the minuscule form often used in Anglo-Saxon and Irish manuscripts derived from the cursive Roman S. The m is of a peculiar shape

column11: as in the Gospels of Lindisfarne written at the close of the seventh century
column12: and the Book of St. Chad. The space below the right-hand portion of the inscription is filled by a plain ribbon pattern.''

column3: `Among the peculiarities of the lettering may be mentioned the form of the D
column4: which reminds one of that occurring twice on Crux Crizdi. The first _m_ in summi is made with the bar
column5: which should be at the top of the three perpendiculars
column6: drawn through them
column7: giving the letter the appearance of an H with three perpendiculars
column8: or two H''S made into one.[1] The R is rather more like a capital H than we have been able to have it represented here. The P has the lower end of the curve seldom joined to the perpendicular. The S is always of the tall or gamma kind
column9: and overshadows the _u_ in _[Gamma]u

column15: '' and in the cross at Tullylease

column3: `The phrase _explicaverit hoc nomen_ refers to the (contracted) name at the top of the stone; for the latter see No. 380.  The formula used in the inscription recurs in Wales on No. 82 (dated early 9th century) and in Ireland

column4: and down the right side of the stone is the inscription in minuscule letters...The letter r is thrice repeated in the Anglo-Saxon form
column5: like n. The stone was figured by Sir S. Meyrick (Cardiganshire
column6: P1. VII. fig. 6)
column7: but the middle and end of the inscription were incorrectly read.''

column3: `Round half-uncials...cut in good style. The abbreviations used are those normally employed in manuscripts of the period. In l. 1 Q with suprascript I is the normal Irish (and Welsh) contraction for _qui_ from the 8th century onwards. U~ (for _uer_) in l. 3 and H with a dot over it (for _hoc_) and N~O~ (for nomen) in 1. 4
column4: the two latter representing abbreviations by suspension
column5: are also normal. The D''s with closed loop and inclined tail are an Irish form met with at Clonmacnois and elsewhere.''

column4: 23: `entirely in Roman capitals
column5: with the exception of the h in the first line ...(all the A''s being turned upside down)...The inscription was rendered by Bishop Gibson (whose reading was adopted by Gough in his subsequent edition of the `Britannia'' and all the more recent writers who had mentioned the stone up to 1859
column6: when I published a memoir and figure of it in the Archaeologia Cambrensis) as follows : `Bodvocus hic jacit
column7: filius Catotis
column8: Irni pronepus
column9: eternali ve domav
column10: i. e. eternali in domo.'' Gibson added the following explanations in support of his reading : `In old inscriptions we often find the letter V where we use O
column11: as here
column12: PRONEPVS for Pronepos (vide Reines. Syntagma Inscript. p. 932)
column13: so that there was no necessity of inventing a character [an oblique line within a circle] made use of in earlier editions of Camden''s work''...With regard to the terminal words of the inscription
column14: Camden adds
column15: `Sepulchres are in old inscriptions often called domus aeternae
column16: but aeternales [eternali] seems a barbarous word. The last words I read aeternali in domo
column17: for in that age sepulchres were called aeternales domus
column18: or rather aeternae (Reines. p. 716)
column19: according to this dystich

column1: `Docta lyre grata et gestu formosa puella
Hic jacet aeterna Sabis humata domo.''
`On carefully looking at this inscription several peculiarities are noticeable
column2: the most important of which is the Greek cross incised upon the truncated top of the stone
column3: extending by a line to the inscription on the face of the stone
column4: thus
column5: it appears to me
column6: clearly indicating that the deceased Bodvoc was a Christian. In the next place
column7: the first name is given as Bodvocus by Camden
column8: overlooking the transverse stroke after the C
column9: clearly intended to turn the name into the genitive ease
column10: Bodvoci
column11: according to the common formula in the inscriptions of this early period in Wales. In the same manner Camden overlooked the cross line at the end of the inscription
column12: which would cause it also to terminate with a genitive name
column13: Vedomavi...The S in Catotis has been misread g
column14: but there is not the slightest indication of the top cross bar...''

column3: `The inscription is in capitals
column4: except the letter _h_
column5: two of the final _i_''s are horizontal
column6: and all the _a_''s  are upside down; _fi_ and _li_ are represented by ligatures
column7: but the letters are otherwise better cut than the average of inscriptions of this kind.''

column3: `The H is half-uncial.  All the A''s are inverted
column4: and the FI
column5: LI of FILIVS are ligatured as usual.  The penultimate letter is ambiguous; it might be V quite as well as L.''

column2: 146: `Roman capitals...with half-uncial H and three ligatures. The A''s
column3: with angular cross-bar
column4: are all inverted. The R''5 in l. 3 have a short
column5: nearly horizontal tail. FI and LI in ll. 2 and 3 are ligatured. The first and last words have the horizontal final -I.''

column3: `The lettering is almost entirely in Roman capitals with a single half-uncial H; the A-s
column4: with angular cross-bar
column5: are inverted
column6: and the R-s in the third line have a horizontal tail. For the `S'' form of G
column7: compare No. 843. There are three ligatures
column8: FI and LI (twice)
column9: and the horizontal terminal I occurs twice

column5: `Among the peculiarities of the lettering may be noticed the first E
column6: which consists of C with a horizontal line joined to the top end of that letter

column9: so that they look like ||. Most of these inscriptions are punched

column3: `I have been led to suppose the terminal word _ahest_ to represent _ejus_
column4: as such is a common termination of the formula `pro anima eius''---as on Samson''s cross `pro anmia ejus
column5: '' on Houelt''s cross at Llantwit `pro anima Res pa(tr)es eus
column6: '' the last word being clearly ejus although misspelt on the stone (Mr. Rhys prints it as correctly written---Notes
column8: and on the smaller cross at Merthyr Mawr `pro anima ejus.'' Mr. Rhys however suggests
column9: `As to Ahest
column10: which it has been tried to distort into ejus
column11: it is probably the name which occurs as Achess in the _Liber Landavensis_
column12: where we have Trefbledgwr Mabaches (p. 32) and Audi Filium Achess (p. 265).'' ''

column3: `In early Medieval Irish z was treated as an equivalent for _st_
column4: and it is fairly certain that our inscriber would not regard his z as the soft sibilant of such words as _zeal_ or _zero_
column5: as that sound was unknown in Celtic
column6: whether Goidelic or Brythonic. One of the most remarkable things about this inscription is
column7: that it seems to represent the author of the inscription''s pronunciation of Latin phonetically: thus we have _inomine_ for in _nmine_
column8: and _anma_ for _nima_; whence in the same way Modern French _me_ for Old French _anme_
column9: Spanish _alma_. The _b_ in __proparabit_ was to be here pronounced _v_ as in _Conbelin_
column10: and as in Latin from the fourth century down: see such forms as _comparabit se biba_ for _comparavit se viva_ in De Rossi''s Christian Inscriptions found in Rome
column11: vol. i
column12: No. 1125. The _o_ in _proparabit_ is of a different origin
column13: being due
column14: no doubt
column15: to confusion of the Latin prefixes _prae_ and _pro_: it is attested elsewhere in Med. Irish _procept_ `teaching''
column16: from the Latin _praeceptum_; while the related Welsh word was _pregeth_
column17: originally meaning the act of teaching
column18: but now only a sermon. It may be pointed out that the phonetic writing is quite of a piece with the simple syntax of the inscription: thus
column19: judging from other instances
column20: we have to take by itself _In nomine. dei summi crux Christi_
column21: or treat it as equivalent to _In nomine dei summi incipit crux Christi_; and then it should have gone on with _quam preparavit Grutne_
column22: but such a construction appears to have been too complicated for the Latinity of the author of this legend.''

column3: `For the formula cf. No. 231. [MARG2/1/1]''"|0|rbook||"Westwood/1879
column5: `The rudeness of the letters and the incorrect orthography of nearly every one of the words of this inscription will perhaps be considered as a sufficient warrant for my reading the last line `ejus'' rather than as the proper name of some other person for the repose of whose soul the cross was erected by Grutne. The letters are rude minuscules
column6: mixed with uncials (such as the Benedictine authors of the `Nouveau Trait de Diplomatique'' would have called semiuncial)
column7: the d open and rounded with the second part a little inclined to the left at top
column8: the S both f and S shaped
column9: the r with the second part much elongated
column10: the g of the minuscule form with the top cross-stroke long. The letters are irregular in size and position in the lines
column11: and of a ruder character than those on the stone of Brancuf. The omission of the n in the first word In (nomine) appears to have been intended simply to prevent duplication of the letters. The same peculiarity occurs on the great cross at Merthyr Mawr. The word `anima'' seems to have been rather troublesome
column12: as we find it not only misspelt here
column13: but on Samson''s cross at Llantwit it is written `anmia'' (although correctly given by Rhys and Hbner).''

column3: `As to the next Margam cross
column4: I had only time to look at it hurriedly in 1897
column5: but I felt confident that it had been correctly read. On my visit in 1898
column6: however
column7: I had plenty of leisure to scrutinise it
column8: and to discover
column9: to my surprise
column10: that we have always misread it
column11: especially the fifth line
column12: which has been treated as _Critdi_...At all events
column13: there is no doubt but that we are to read the beginning of this legend as _inomine_
column14: and I am inclined to read the end Anest
column15: and to regard that as an earlier form of the woman''s name Nest: the perpendicular of the _n_ in Anest is no taller than that of the first _n_ in _inomine_
column16: but it is straight or perpendicular
column17: while that of the letter in _inomine_ is not really so
column18: as it bends backwards a bit at the top. However
column19: I should not quarrel with anyone who wishes still to read _Ahest_
column20: provided he does not further try to make it a form of the Latin word _eius_. The letter which has been read t in the impossible form _Critdi = Christi_ is not a _t_
column21: but has the shape of a z; but it may be doubted whether it was intended for z rather than for s. Thus we have s and sometimes a reversed s; and on the Clydey stone of Dobituci we have the former made with angles instead of curves
column22: and looking
column23: consequently
column24: like an inverted z
column25: namely
column26: in _FILIVS_. So our instance here may be a reversed s similarly angulated into the shape of z. But
column27: on the other hand
column28: the inscriber may have intended a z
column29: and in that case he probably congratulated himself on achieving a novelty in the spelling of the word Christi.''

column3: `Round half-uncials

column3: `The lettering is in crude half-uncials with one square E (l. 8) and common manuscript abbreviations: `inomine'' for in nomine (cf Nos. 928
column5: `di'' for dei and `sumi'' for summi (see p. 27 above). Though there is no spacing of words
column6: two punctuation stops occur
column7: one single and one triple.''"|MARG2/2/1

column15: `The Ogham scores depend upon a stem-line cut on the surface of the stone
column16: running vertically up the dexter side of the cross-bearing face and bending at right angles
column17: continuing horizontally under its upper margin.  The intention of the stone-cutter was obviously to write

column1: ` ``Name of Colman the Pilgrim.''''  But he has blundered so badly that he has made the decipherment of the inscription a very difficult matter.  At best
column2: the  inscription is a ``scholastic'''' essay.

column1: `On the vertical part of the stem line he wrote ANM COL.  He then realized that if he continued here he would have his N at the angle
column2: and
column3: consequently
column4: awkwardly cramped; or else
column5: if he carried on past the angle
column6: it would run into the B-half of the M.  Accordingly
column7: he skipped the angle and wrote MAN on the horizontal branch of his stem-line.  He then wrote AIL
column8: the beginning of AILITHIR
column9: before he saw that this word would have to be shortened to fit into the available space
column10: which he had rashly reduced by cutting the second cross.  A feeling of reverence may have prevented him from making room for himself by breaking this away.  Accordingly
column11: he squeezed an L into the space between the A and the I---its cramped nature is obvious---thus abolishing the first I of the word AILITHIR
column12: and adapting the I which he had already fashioned to represent the second I of this word.  He next had to dispose of the L which was already on the stone
column13: and for which he would be obliged to substitute a T.  This he ingeniously effected by cutting a line joining the distal ends of the two scores
column14: thus turning these underline scores into overline scores
column15: and then adding one more
column16: and only one
column17: in the orthodox position above the main stem-line.  This gave him the three overline scores of the T.  He then proceeded with the final IR
column18: which just filled the available space
column19: though it went beyond the range of the stem line which he had laid out at the beginning.  In order to make his correction clear
column20: he wrote in the turn of the angle of the stem line
column21: which still remained blank
column22: the letters O.L.Th---the Th being represented by the O-_forfid_---meaning _ L
column23: Th_---``from `L'' [make] `Th.'' ''''  This gives us a neat demonstration of the consonantal value of that character
column24: and a further corroboration of the Greek origin of the Ogham script.  It is a rare example of a _lapidary_ gloss
column25: similar to the glosses with which ancient Irish manuscripts are pestered.  There is some excuse for the reading given by Bishop Graves
column27: although criticism to which he submitted it

column3: `Macalister''s ingenious interpretation may be correct...and that the peculiarities can be explained as an attempt to correct mistakes made during its execution.''

column3: `The beginning of the first line is gone

column6: on examining it very carefully again

column9: `so that it is hard to say whether _u_ is to be represented as V or as U

column18: which has been sometimes taken for a t. The _n_''s vary considerably : that of hanc has its first perpendicular prolonged somewhat below the level of the other

column27: an _a_

column14: charter or document (see Seebohm''s _Tribal System_

column2: the words _in proprium_ and _in grefium_ seem to show that in this inscription we have a reference to a formal document commemorating some such transaction as the gift of a piece of land to a religious community. Compare a similar document on the Llanllyr Cross
column3: _Arch. Camb._

column1: `As to the formula _I(n) nomine Dei Patris et Fili Spiritus Sancti_
column2: we have had it already on the Cross of Houelt
column3: and it seems to mean
column4: ``In the name of God the Father and of the Son the Holy Spirit.'''' I have shown both to Mr. F. C. Conybeare
column5: who has devoted to them a brief notice in his Paulician work called ``The Key of Truth.'''' Among other things he says : ``This formula takes us straight back to _The Shepherd_ of Hermas
column6: in which the Son of God is equated with the Holy Spirit
column7: and it also exactly embodies the heresy of which Basil deplored the prevalence in the eastern regions of Asia Minor. These inscriptions
column8: therefore
column9: rudely disturb the ordinary assumption
column10: that the early Celtic Church was ``catholic in doctrine and practice''''; as if Bede had meant nothing when he studiously ignored St. Patrick and denied that the British bishops even preached the Word''''. He says of the other formula
column11: _In nomine Dei Summi_
column12: that it seems to be both praetrinitarian and connected with the series of inscriptions in honour of [some Greek]
column13: found in Asia Minor
column14: and referred by Schurer and Franz Cumont to Jewish influence''''. He ends his note with the words : ``The survival of such formulae on these old Welsh crosses explains why Bede rejected the baptism of the British Christians
column15: and why Aldhelm (A.D. 715) denied that they had the _Catholicae fidei regula_ at all.''''[1] The absence in our inscriptions of anything explicitly trinitarian is remarkable
column16: and I should like to see the question more fully discussed. Lastly
column17: I am reminded by the Editor of the remarkable fact that no representations of the Trinity
column18: or symbols of the Trinity
column19: occur in Celtic art.

column1: `[1] Mr. Conybeare has since had a paper on the ``Welsh Church'''' printed in the _Transactions_ of the Hon. Society of Cymmrodorion.''

column3: discusses the metre of the inscription and then goes on to state: `Lastly
column4: as to the nature of the transaction referred to as committed to a written document
column5: here called _grefium_
column6: that is _graphium_
column7: I have no doubt that it was a legal acquisition by the deceased of the plot of ground which was to be his burial place
column8: where this cross
column9: probably of the seventh or eight century
column10: was originally set up.  Plenty of illustrations occur in the Christian epitaphs of the Continent
column11: such as those of Rome collected by De Rossi.  We have another Celtic instance
column12: to be mentioned shortly
column13: in the case of the Llanllyr stone
column14: where a saint is also made a party to the transaction.  The country round Merthyr Mawr was decidedly within the sphere of the influence of St. Iltutus or Illtud
column15: but the state of the legend does not enable one to define the part which the saint was supposed to act through his successor at the time here in question: probably the transaction would not have been considered valid without the latter''s express approval.''

column7: 326--327: `The lettering of the Latin inscription is Roman capitals

column9: with oblique top bar and two horizonatal bars below instead of one
column10: is a well known Early Christian form
column11: found in continental inscriptions fron the late fourth to the seventh century A.D.
column12: though rare in this country. The remarkable symbol used for S in ll. 3 and 5 appears to be without parallel among contemporary inscriptions either in this country or on the Continent.  In both cases it is placed above the line
column13: as though a mark of abbreviation rather than a true letter.''

column5: CA (l. 4)
column6: and VV (l. 5) conjoined. The E-shaped form of the F is not uncommon on contemporary continental inscriptions
column7: but occurs more rarely in Britain (cf. Nos. 27

column9: of the S is based on the Greek letter [Sigma] (_sigma_) (cf. Nos. 160

column6: followed by the words BARRECT{I} CARANTI
column7: leading to the suggestion that the genitive form of the names of the deceased individuals commemorated by many of these early stones was used after the implied formula DIS MANIBUS.''

column2: 172: `The use of the pagan Roman formula _Dis Manibus_ on an Early Christian tombstone is without parallel in Wales
column3: but occurs widely in Italy and the provinces generally. Commonly
column4: but not invariably
column5: the formula was accompanied by a specifically Christian phrase or symbol. The present stone may therefore be Christian.''"|n|rcaps||"Westwood/1876

column1: [The inscription] shows connnections with another Brecon example---that at Llanfihangel Cwm-du [LFIC1/1] --- points to the resemblence being the Greek angular cross-bars to the A''s and C''s. and the conjoined IT and then small L.  The main differences are the absence of half-uncial forms and the forked serifs at Nant Crew.  The M with the central angle stopping short of the base line (another Greek form) is Paralleled in Pembrokeshire and Caernarvonshire.  All these inscriptions are fifth to sixth century types
column2: and it is to this date that the Nant Crew Stone must be assigned.''"|NANTC/1/1

column4: 84--85: `The G seems to be {g}; the L inclines to be {acute L}
column5: while the C approaches <
column6: and the N is written {backwards-N}

column8: possibly to indicate the I
column9: somewhat after the fashion of Roman inscriptions
column10: but the I may be there as a very close parallel to the {N}:  I could not decide with the light from below.  The F is much the usual type
column11: with its lower arm drooping a little.  The second limb of the V tends to end with a slight curvature
column12: except the last V
column13: which ends well under the roof of the T.  The R is rather an elegant letter
column14: but its perpendicular is prolonged somewhat beneath the line.  The final I is of the usual horizontal kind.  I had no time to try to take a rubbing of the stone
column15: and even had I time
column16: I do not think it could have been done to any advantage while the stone is in its present position.  The letters GLO are very faint
column17: and some of the others are not much less faint; so I gather that all that face had been a good deal exposed to the weather
column18: or more likely
column19: to the tread of feet

column1: Rhys visited the stone again in 1909 after it had been removed from the wall and stated: `a difficulty which still remains
column2: as to the NI.  What I represented as fairly certain consisted of V and an I
column3: which taken together
column4: would make an N with an inverted diagonal
column5: and leave the I a matter of doubt.  I am now inclined to read the whole word MAGLOCVVI''.

column2: 68: `now that the whole has been got out and cleaned the readings allow no room for doubt except at one point in the Latin version...Now the M and A come out large and sprawling. except that the top of the A is damaged; the G is not of the shape I had supposed

column4: and that of CLUTOR{I} ends under the roof of the T
column5: which is a rather tall letter
column6: though not so tall as the R
column7: which is taller than all the letters near it
column8: just as the O is somewhat smaller than the other letters.  The F is a rather decadent letter with its short bar drooping; the last and final I is horizontal.   There is no trouble as to the reading of any of the letters except at the end of the first name.  The previous time I suggested {backwards-N}I
column9: though I could not closely examine the spot.  Now
column10: on closer scrutiny
column11: I cannot satisfy myself as to the presence of {N}I : if one reads {N} there is no I
column12: and if one reads I there is no {N}. I  was not a little influenced by Lloyd
column13: the mason
column14: who insisted  that the last letter but one was a V
column15: like the V immediately preceding it.  So far as the roughness of the stone permits one to decide
column16: the I does not seem to touch the nearest writing before it : that is
column17: it could not be {N} but VI
column18: though there is no objection to {N} as such
column19: for it occurs on the Vitaliani stone close by.  On the whole I think one must read the Latin gentive as MAGLOCVVI ad the whole as MAGLOCVVI FILI CLVTO{I}.''

`Along the upper angle of the stone runs an ogham inscription
column4: for the first time represented in the accompanying Plate...The inscription occupies 21 inches
column5: and is composed as follows
column6: reading from below
column7: as usual.  First are three short strokes to the right (T)
column8: then four dots on the angle of the stone (E)
column9: then three short strokes to the left (F)
column10: then an obscure dot on the angle (A)
column11: and two straight strokes to the right (D)
column12: then five marginal dots with about three-quarters of an inch between them (I)
column13: followed at a little distance (1 1/4) by a single dot (A)
column14: then five straight strokes to the right (Q)
column15: and at the top are five dots (I) on the angle of the stone
column16: which is somewhat obliquely truncated.  The three terminal letters
column17: AQI
column18: would seem to imply the previous M to make the word (M)AQ(U)I=MAC of the usual formula; but although there is a space between the last of the five dots=I
column19: and the dot representing the second A (which should be a single oblique stroke crossing the angle of the stone
column20: and extending on both the right and left sides of the angle)
column21: yet our various rubbings and drawings
column22: as well as in Mr. Brash''s notice
column23: there is no trace of such a stroke.  The oblique fracture at the top of the stone may have possibly broken off some more of the ogham characters
column24: which might have been the letters of the father''s name.''

column7: ` ``Here lies Richard with his true sheep'''' suggests a faithful Parish Priest; and a Richard
column8: who died in 1305
column9: was actually vicar of the parish
column10: and in all probability is the owner of the monument.  The inscriptions at the side are less easy to explain
column11: though their purport is clear enough...

column1: `In passing we note the curious affectation of the literary artifice known as _chiasmus_--- the alternation of subject and predicate.  There is some doubt about the reading of the second name
column2: owing to a fracture of the surface of the stone; but the second is clear enough
column3: and I can say only that I have never seen anything like it.  Who were these people?  How does it come that the maker of the stone was allowed to advertise his handiwork in larger letters and in a more conspicuous place than the epitaph itself?  In ancient times the name of the maker is very rarely recorded on such monuments; and even in our days of ``business methods'''' it is not obtruded.  And though in my time I have seen many thousands of tombstones
column4: ancient and modern
column5: I never saw elsewhere a record of the _purchaser_ of the monument.  I commend this stone to those who have access to old records; it would be interesting to find out something more about Mereb and Hurum
column6: and the reason why their commercial transactions were apparently accounted of greater importance than the commemoration of a faithful shepherd of the sheep of Newcastle Bridgend.''

column2: 164: `The names [MERERB and HURUM] are strange
column3: and it is hard to see why the commercial transactions of these persons are so conspicuously recorded.''

column1: `Then comes AGRUM DA. I think the last letter is A
column2: not O ; its sinister side is flattened; and I think further that I can trace in the rubbing the little projections above and below which distinguish the letter from an O. If the QUOD of the line but one above is meant to agree with AGRUM
column3: it should have been QUEM; but I need not say that anything is possible in the Latinity of these inscriptions.

column1: `In the next line we have [A over T] G L I G U I S
column2: of which for the moment I need only say that the minuscular T
column3: beneath the A
column4: presumably completes the word DAT.

column1: `A peculiar character begins each of the two following lines. I take it to be a compendium for ET
column2: found frequently in MSS.
column3: and in stone in the inscription on Caldey Island (for I have quite abandoned an interpretation which I once adventured of this inscription
column4: which gave a different meaning to the character). Passing over the next line for the present
column5: we come to the last line
column6: which appears to read ET FILI EPILI --- recalling the Epillus whose name appears on the coins of the Lemovices
column7: and a lady named Epilla
column8: who dedicated a votive inscription found at Luxeuil. The line above is disturbed with horizontal strokes
column9: like that already noticed on the other face ; it looks like ET NER[A over T]. The N is of the minuscular form ; and I am tempted into the mazes of speculation by the resemblance of this name to HERTTAN
column10: found on one of the Merthyr Mawr chapel inscriptions. The minuscular N and minuscular H are very like one another ; have we here one and the same man
column11: who may have been called either Nerttan or Herttan? If so
column12: we must infer that when our scribe wrote [A over T]
column13: he meant to produce a compendium for TAN. Indeed
column14: there must be some reason why he twice superposed the _a_ to the _t_ within this short inscription
column15: with no apparent reason. If this be sound
column16: we must return to the line above and read it T A N G L I G U I S
column17: the initial T being part of the last word of the preceding line ; which opens further speculations about a possible ANGLICUS having crossed the border
column18: and having become sufficiently naturalized to witness a legal transaction. For that these are the names of witnesses to Arthmail''s deed of gift seems to be the most likely hypothesis.

column1: `_A priori_ one would expect the inscriptions on two faces of a stone fragment to be of the same extent. As there are seven lines of writing on the one face
column2: and only four on the other
column3: I presume that a space for three lines is broken or defaced on the latter side.

column1: `To take the shorter inscription (Fig. 7) first. Obviously it began like one at Margam
column2: IN NOMINE (perhaps written INOMINE) DI SUM (M)I. INOMINE is all broken away except the bottom curve of the E; I think I can trace indications of the bottom of other letters in the rubbing
column3: but without complete assurance. DI SUMI is plain enough
column4: in the second line. A line cut through and below these letters is possibly a guide-line for the engraver; there are similar lines in the Merthyr Mawr inscriptions. But are these lines on the Ogmore stone (for there are others on the other side) certainly artificial? [Yes! V.E.N.-W.] After SUMI there come three letters which appear to be CRO
column5: though the C is not of the shape that we should expect the cutter of this inscription to cut ; its curve is too shallow. But I cannot see how else to take it. The next line begins S I
column6: followed by two uncertain letters. In the second of these
column7: the rubbing suggests a rather square-bottomed U to me rather than the minuscule H of your pencilling; and indeed if these letters are not CROS IHU
column8: I am unable to conjecture how to take them. The Goidelic word cros
column9: instead of the Latin crux
column10: arouses suspicion; but the interpretation will have to stand
column11: so far as I am concerned
column12: till someone thinks of something better. The next word is G E N (I take this letter for a minuscular N) T I --- GENTI. In the following line is the name BRANCUI---presumably the genitive of the name which we find at Baglan
column13: BRANCU (not Brancuf
column14: pace Westwood). A similar (feminine?) name follows in the next line
column15: B R A N C I(?) E
column16: and I suppose the lost next line began with FILI. So that my tentative interpretation of this inscription is :

column1: `[IN NOMINE]/ DI SUM(M)I CRO/S(?) IH(ES)U(?) GENTI/ BRANCUT/ BRANCIE(?)/ [FILI   ].
` ``In the Name of the Most High God
column2: the Cross of Jesus for the family of Brancu
column3: (son of) Brancia. . . .'''' ''

column3: `There is plenty of analogy for _cives_ and _consobrinos_ as nominatives singular...and for instances of the final sibilant omitted
column4: as in _cive_ and _magistrati_ ... The conversion of _magistratu~s_ into _magistrati_ is also to be put down as Latin
column5: and not as a whim of the Celtic inscriber...[discussion of names in appropriate table]...The accentuation of  _Venedotis_ I take to have been that of the Brythonic gentive _Venedo~tos_
column6: which was presumably _Vendo~tos_; the later forms are Gwyned
column7: `Veenedota

column10: _ and _Gwyndawt

column3: `Venedos is the Celtic form of the Welsh Gwynedd
column4: the ancient name applied to NW. Wales (comprising roughly Caernarvonshire and the island of Anglesey)
column5: which was thus
column6: as the present inscription shows
column7: already separately identified in the sub-Roman period. Consobrinos is the popular-Latin form of the literary consobrinus. Magistrati (for magistratus)
column8: by attraction of a 4th Declension noun into the 2nd Declension
column9: can be paralleled in inscriptions of the classical period. This is the only known instance of the occurrence in Britain of the terms civis and magistratus in an early Christian inscription. Their use in the present context is of special interest as. implying the existence of an ordered system of government in NW. Wales in sub-Roman times. It is. possible that an administrative district had been constituted already in the Roman period
column10: centring on the Roman station of Caernarvon (Segontium).'' Mention of the civic antecedents of early Christians in their epitaphs. was not usual
column11: but parallels can be cited on contemporary inscriptions in Italy
column12: N. Africa
column13: and Gaul[2]''.

column3: `Justinus was consul in A.D. 540
column4: which is therefore the date of

column2: consul in 541
column3: were the last Roman consuls to be cited on monuments in the western world
column4: their names continuing to be used retrospectively for dating purposes as late as the early 7th century in Burgundy
column5: where the Roman consular system of dating persisted after it had been ousted elsewhere in Gaul. The use of Justinus'' name was limited to the monuments of Lyon and district
column6: that of Basilius'' to those of Vienne and district.[3] The present inscription would thus seem to indicate contacts between Wales and Gaul (Burgundy) in the 6th century (cf. No. 33).

column2: ii
column3: pp. lx
column4: lxxi. Cf. No. 101.''

column2: argues that given the continued use of consular dating in Burgundy until the mid seventh century

column5: in reality

column7: `We found no indubitable trace of the letters IC or HIC; but there is room enough certainly left vacant for the former ; and I think we noticed a part of the I
column8: and a little part of what may have been a C.  I have very little doubt that they were both once there.  It so happens that at this part of the Stone there is a sort of patch
column9: as it were in relief on the face of it.  The inscriber was
column10: however
column11: not deterred by this
column12: for he began his IACIT on it
column13: though there is now very little left of the first I
column14: and the A is partly gone.  There were some letters before BECCVRI in the last line ; but they are gone
column15: excepting a trace of the tops of some of them
column16: as the stone is chipped in that part...`As to the other characters
column17: the FI consist of an F with a small I attached to its lower horizontal limb.  The NA are conjoint in both lines.  So far as the stone is concerned
column18: it is difficult to decide beyond doubt as to the last letter but one of the first line
column19: whether it is a P or an R.  There is there all that is necessary to make P ; but there is more
column20: namely
column21: a nearly horizontal bar proceeding towards the right from the lower end of the perpendicular
column22: just as though the oblique line of an R had fallen down.  On the whole
column23: however
column24: I am strongly inclined to think that the letter is to be read P
column25: and that the rest in the result of a chipping of the surface of the stone...But I have not yet done with the letters.  The first letter of CVNACI has lost its lower part
column26: as it stood on a part which has been broken off
column27: possibily before the stone left its original position on a grave.  The first vowel of BECCVRI is somewhat rounded like a Greek [epsilon] ; the second C is angular
column28: like a very open V on its side ; and the VR are conjoint.  I do not know of any other instance of this ; and it is possible that I have not hit on the right reading.  The last part of the R is rather distinguished by colour than by any depression or groove
column29: as the surface on both sides of it has flaked off.  The possible remains of this line are
column31: BECC^LVR^B^PI. [Name encoded according to CISP method as print version not possible.]

column1: [In Postscript]  `We carefully examined the inscription again
column2: and thought we found undeniable traces of the adverb IC.  Moreover
column3: it does not seem so correct to say that the A of _jacit_ [sic.] has been partly worn away
column4: as that it was never finished
column5: owing probably to the hardness of the superficial patch alluded to.  I believe now more firmly than ever that the letter I have ventured to read P cannot have been anything else ;  and Mr. Auden
column6: after very careful examination of it with a glass
column7: agrees with me.  As a piece of guesswork
column8: I may add that I find that CIVI would just fit the remains of the letters preceding _Beccvri_.  It will be remembered that CIVE does duty for _civis_ on one of the Penmachno stones.''

column5: `Col. Francis thus speaks of this stone
column6: which `was found in 1839 at Port Talbot
column7: between Neath and the Roman station of Bovium. The older inscription
column8: if we may depend on the fidelity of the engraving
column9: is dedicated
column10: not
column11: as some have pretended
column12: to _Maximian_
column13: but to _Maximin_
column14: who bears upon his coins the title of _Invictus_ (as upon the stone)
column15: which is not found on those of _Maximian_. The inscription as it now stands may be read thus---Imp. C. Fla. Val. Maximino Invicto Augus(to). But on looking closer we are led to believe that the first part belongs to a still older inscription
column16: as the C. Fla. Val. (Caius Flavius Valerius) were names which never belonged to Maximin
column17: whose name was Galerius Valerius. (The names of the two Maximians were ``Marcus Aurelius Valerius Maximianus'''' and ``Galerius Valerius Maximianus.'''') The appellation of C. Flavius Valerius belongs to the second Severus
column18: and it is probable that to him this stone was originally inscribed
column19: but that subsequently his name had been erased to give place to that of Maximin by some person who carelessly or ignorantly overlooked the prenomens.''

column1: `The name of the Emperor Maximinus here recorded (with the title INVICTUS) also occurs in an inscription found in Cumberland
column2: given by Horsley (Brit. Rom. p. 192
column3: No. 40; and conf. Hubner
column4: Inscr. Lat. vii. 1158).''

column3: `This inscription is outside our scope
column4: but it may be observed that the Imperial _praenomina_ are inaccurate.  There were two emperors called Maximinus---Gaius Iulius Verus Maximinus (A.D. 235--238) and Galerius Valerius Maximinus (A.D. 308--314).  The latter is doubtless the person intended.  Flauius Valerius _Seuerus_ was emperor in 306--7; apparently his _praenomina_ were by some error ascribed in the inscription to his sucessor.  Such an error would be most likely to take place just at a change of reign
column5: so that we may confidently date this inscription to A.D. 308.''

column3: `The inscription identifies the monument as a Roman milestone
column4: set up originally in the time of the Emperor Maximinus (A.D. 309-13)
column5: presumably to mark the repair or rehabilitation of the Roman main S. Wales road where it passed through or near the site of modern Port Talbot.''"|0|rcaps||"Westwood/1879

column1: `A photograph and rubbing of the stone were submitted to Dr. Macalister... [who states]

` ``The text presents some curious features.  The first thing that calls for notice is the combination of vertical and horizontal lines of writing.  This is very rare; the nearest parallel that I can recall is one of the Penmachno stones
column2: but that belongs to a different class
column3: as it is written in Roman capitals.  The second noteworthy thing is the solitary `N'' forming a second line all to itself in the _vertical_ part of the inscription.

column1: ` ``These two points suggest to me that the stone is of the nature of a palimpsest.  I take it that originally it bore nothing more than the cross and the words `CRUX XPI.''  At this stage the stone was identical in type with the slab at Llangyfelach
column2: which also bears a cross and nothing more than the same words `CRUX XPI''; but the cross in the latter example is more ornate
column3: and evidently later than the very simple and primitive Port Talbot example.  These crosses are to be considered rather as devotional than as commemorative...

column2: I take it
column3: the Port Talbot stone was broken
column4: after which it was re-appropriated for the purpose of commemorating the person named on the other inscription.  That is my explanation of the change in the direction of the lines; had

column1: the two inscriptions been contemporary I feel sure that they would have been written in parallel lines.[1]  I am inclined to think that we have the whole of the second inscription
column2: and that it was intended to read GELUGUIN.  Had the line of writing been much longer
column3: we should have expected the superfluous ``n'''' to have been written
column4: for the convenience of the reader
column5: under the _last_ rather than under the first letter.  Moreover
column6: the proportions of the surviving part of the cross suggest that there is not a very great length of the stem lost
column7: and as the cross would most likely occupy as much as possible of the space available
column8: I do not suppose that the slab was ever very large
column9: or that there was room upon it for many more letters---not enough to make another word.  Impressions are
column10: of course
column11: very fallacious
column12: but certainly I derive from the photograph an impression of an inscription that has just fitted into the space which the present size of the stone allows.''

column3: `Round half-uncials
column4: coarsely picked in good style. Some of the letters are lightly clubbed.''

column5: `My reading of the whole is _Rinaci Nomena_
column6: which is
column7: however
column8: only the beginning of my difficulties.  At first I thought _Nomena_ must  be a proper name
column9: and that the whole meant _Rinaci filia Nomena_; but I know of no other instance of such a formula with _filia_ or _filius_ left out.  Another way of looking at the inscription would be to regard it as consisting of a name with an epithet appended to it
column10: and treat _Rinaci_ as a nominative feminine
column11: say for _Rinacis_; but the conjecture has not led me to any solution of the difficulty.  So I fall back on the possibility of Nomena standing for Latin _nomina_
column12: just as we have _Emeret-o_ on another Pembrokeshire stone for _Emerito_.  But what would _Rinaci Nomina_ mean?

column1: `Dr. Stokes suggested to me that _nomena_ is simply an instance of our Celts having made _nomen_ into a feminine; and he adds that the Latin _agnomen_
column2: when taken into Irish
column3: was also treated as a feminine.  This
column4: I think
column5: is the most probable interpretation
column6: and RINACI NOMENA would accordingly mean _The Name of Rinac_
column7: which proves an exact parallel to the formula of certain Ogam inscriptions occurring in Ireland.  They usually begin with the word _amn_
column8: followed by the genitive of the deceased person''s name; and _anm_ represents an early Goidelic form
column9: _anmen_
column10: which in modern Irish is _ainm_
column11: ``a name''''.  It happens that none of these _anm_ inscriptions can be proved to belong to the oldest class of Ogams; but there seems to be no reason to suppose that the formula is not ancient.''

column1: `The introduction of the initials of the names of the Saviour
column2: or of the Alpha and Omega
column3: at the top of Christian inscriptions appears to have been an evident imitation of the ancient Roman formula
column4: D.M. (_diis manibus_)
column5: applied in similar situations. It is of the greatest rarity in our Christian lapidary monuments

column2: 208--210: `The use of Alpha and Omega as Christian symbols on monuments goes back to the earliest times
column3: in Britain[3] as on the Continent. The monograms IHC and XPC (derived from the earlier Greek two-letter forms IC and XC) and their Latin equivalent HS and XPS[4] are later
column4: their earliest appearance on monuments in Ireland[5] and in Wales (No. 125) dating apparently in the first half of the 9th century.

column2: 516 (Kirkmadrine

column1: `[4] The Greek contractions IC and XC
column2: and their three-letter variants IHC and XPC
column3: were in vogue in the E. Roman Empire apparently from the 3rd century A.D. onwards. By the end of the 7th century the Greek three-letter forms
column4: with their Latin equivalents IHS and XPS
column5: are found in use in Irish and English manuscripts
column6: where the Greek forms remain a distinctive local feature until the 9th century. In the latter century they were adopted also on the Continent

This occurred just at the point where a crack had unfortunately taken place. column1: Macalister/1922a. 32: `Some have supposed an ellipsis of POSVIT [Stone] of E
column2: son of D: C
column3: his mother [set it up].  This seems unnatural
column4: however; it would not be obvious
column5: even to the contemporaries of the persons concerned
column6: that such was the intention.  The simplest
column7: and I believe in every way the best
column8: interpretation is arrived at by regarding the second and third lines as a later addition.

column1: `The stone was first set up to commemorate Evalos
column2: son of Dencuos.  Accordingly
column3: his name was cut in one line
column4: running symmetrically down the middle of the stone as though no other inscription had been intended.   When
column5: at some later time Cuniovende died
column6: her memorial was added in the vacant space between Evalos''s epitaph and the edge of the stone.  The stone [wa]s still recognised as Evalos''s; therefore while his name is in the genitive
column7: hers is in the nominative.  It is as though we construed it ``Stone of E.; here lies also C.''''  It is impossible to determine whether the word EIVS belongs to Evalos or Dencuos.  Perhaps the balance of probability inclines to the latter; it seems psychologically more natural that the two inscriptions should be drawn up with the same person in genitive relationship.  At least in such a modern inscription as ``Here lies Thomas
column8: son of John Smith ... also Mary
column9: his mother
column10: '''' we should naturally refer ``his'''' to John
column11: rather than to Thomas.   Had Cuniovende been wife of Dencuos and mother of Evalos we should have expected ``uxor eius'''' rather than ``mater eius.'''' ''

column3: `The first of the three lines of the inscription runs down the central axis of the inscribed face
column4: and must be taken as the original legend.  The other three words are in two lines
column5: squeezed in at the side
column6: and certainly added later
column7: as the result of a subsequent death in the family.  The lettering would have been laid out differently
column8: and most likely the formula would have differed to some extent
column9: had the inscription been cut all at one time. Cuniovenda was probably mother of Evalus
column10: and presumably wife of Dencuus; but as the inscription stands it is not clearly defined wo whom _eius_ refers.''

column3: `For the formula of filiation cf. No. 258.''"|0|rcaps||"Rhys/1874
column5: `The stone...seems to read in the first line EVALI FILI DENCVI.  At any rate Mr. Llywareh Reynolds
column6: of Jesus College
column7: Oxford
column8: who assisted me in the inspection of this stone
column9: agreed with me that there can be no doubt as to the V{I}
column10: which Mr. Longueville Jones had missed. As to reading C instead of his O
column11: I am not certain
column12: and even Q might be possible.''

column3: `The letters are somewhat debased Roman capitals rather finely cut. Several of the letters are conjoined
column4: and the whole is to be read---

column1: `In the first line the letter O seems to be the last in it
column2: because the sinking away of the surface with an edge running across the stone is evidently older than the letters themselves
column3: and hence Mr. H. L. Jones was inclined to think the word to which this letter belongs was contained [continued] in the second line...The V and A in the first line and the V N of the second line are conjoined in the usual manner.
p. 332) considers the last portion of the first line to read DENCV{I}
column4: adding
column5: `At any rate Mr. Llywareh Reynolds
column6: of Jesus College
column7: Oxford
column8: who assisted me in the inspection of this stone
column9: agreed with me that there can be no doubt as to the V{I}
column10: which Mr. Longueville Jones had missed. As to reading C instead of his O
column11: I am not certain
column12: and even Q might be possible.'' And in his Lectures (Pembrokeshire List
column13: No. 73) he adopts the reading as Dencui
column14: and the whole of the second line as one word.''

column3: `Mr. Edward Owen...rather shook my confidence
column4: as he read the first line EVALI FILI DENOV{I}.  To understand the difference it is necessary to mention that between the C and the V there is a sort of step across a part of the face of the stone
column5: so that the letters V{I} are on a lower level than the preceding ones; and if I remember rightly
column6: they do not appear in the version in the _Lapidarium Walliae_ (pl.52
column7: fig 2).  Now the C ends on the step I have mentioned
column8: and the edge of the step is uneven and probably a little damaged of old.   So here comes the uncertainty whether one is to read C or O; but in favour of the former I may observe
column9: that it would be very similar in shape to the C in the name _Cuniovende_.  Other points worthy of notice in connection with this inscription are
column10: that the V of DENCV{I} and of EIVS has its second arm curved...and that in the former instance the first arm is also curved to a slight extent.  Lastly
column11: the V of EVALI forms a conjoint character with the A
column12: but the L is a separate letter in this case.''

column3: `There is a doubt as to the first O
column4: since it is imperfect
column5: but the last time I looked at it I thought it too nearly a complete circle to be a _C_
column6: to which I had been in the habit of giving the preference.''

column3: `A sketch of the _Evali_ inscription at Spittal
column4: which Mr. Allen reads EVALI FILI DENO | CVNIOVENDE | MATER EIUS
column5: that is
column6: with the ligatures resolved...I read it differently
column7: for I take his first O to be C
column8: and near it comes a small step beginning a slightly lower level of the surface.  Beyond that little step I found the letters V{I}; that is
column9: the reading would be DENCVI
column10: which as _De~n-cu~-_ I should equate with a Mediaeval Irishman''s name _Danch_. Philologically _Deno_ looks rather intractable
column11: _Denovi_ would perhaps be less so; but no consideration of that order can be allowed to rule the reading.  The stone must be examined again.[1]

column1: `[1] Since the above was written I have

column3: `The inscription has been read by everyone
column4: since Westwood
column5: MACARITINI FILI BERIC[I]
column6: the initial MA being a ligature formed thus--- {M/A}. After careful examination of the inscription on two occasions
column7: however
column8: I have satisfied myself that this ligature should be ignored
column9: and that the name is simply CARITINI. In front of the C there is a character like A
column10: which is certainly a modern addition to the inscription (extending the word ``modern'''' backward to include the time of Lhwyd
column11: for the mark was there when he tried to read the writing). It is in a different technique (punched
column12: not rubbed) from the rest of the letters. Between it and the C there is a quite natural triangular flaw in the surface of the stone
column13: which makes the second half of the supposed monogram.

column2: it seems to have escaped notice that there was at one time a second line of writing on the stone. The tops of three letters are left---insufficient for a restoration of the text
column3: but at least worth putting on record. These are: a C
column4: underneath (or
column5: having regard to the normal upright position of the stone
column6: to the right of) the horizontal I of CARITIN{I}; an A
column7: underneath the monogram FI of FILI
column8: and an L or an I
column9: underneath the monogram LI of the same word.

column7: however

column9: to which attention is now called

column2: 222: `The letters on this stone at Capel Brithdir are of a debased Roman character
column3: passing into minuscules
column4: and closely resembling those of the CATAMANVS inscription at Llangadwaladr in Anglesey.  Whatever date Dr. Petrie assigns to that
column5: may be accepted
column6: within certain limits
column7: as the same for this stone. The character used for A
column8: which is thoroughly barbarous in form
column9: is nearly the same on both stones ; at least
column10: the similarity is sufficient to lead to the supposition of contemporaneous execution. The letter R occurs twice in this inscription
column11: and is also very debased
column12: for it assumes the form
column13: so widely different from the Roman type
column14: which is found on other Welsh stones and in some MSS. down to as late a period as the thirteenth century. The letter M here takes the minuscule character ; and N
column15: with the cross-stroke intended to be horizontal
column16: is also debased. The form of G is commonly met with on other Welsh stones
column17: and it resembles that of the Fardel stone from Devonshire
column18: but departs rather more widely from the original and normal character of that letter. There are two forms for S on this stone
column19: not at all resembling each other: the first that occurs approaching the shape
column20: which it is found retaining down to the tenth century ; the second still preserving some trace of the old Roman type. Two letters were much injured
column21: the first being U
column22: at the beginning of the third line
column23: of which only the lower portion remains
column24: the other being I
column25: at the end of the same line
column27: though certainly there
column28: is so faint as to have almost led to a doubt in the critical mind of Mr. Stephens. The first E in the first line is defective at the lower part.

column2: 386--??: `... in a notebook belonging to Edward Lhwyd ... His drawing ... is crucial to the argument .... The name _Porius_ and the whole of the second line of the inscription reading _hic in tumulo iacit_ were thus exactly the same then as now on the stone itself
column3: and it is only the last line that requires further attention.  Lhwyd''s notebook is dated 1698 and at that time he read and wrote down the words _homo pianus fuit_.

column1: `Lewis Morris visited the site and afterwards made the following note on a page of his printed copy of Geoffrey of
Monmouth''s _Gesta Regum Britanniae_: `In Mr. E. Llwyd''s notes on Camden''s _Britannia_
column3: there is a mistake in the inscription which he reads _Porius hic in tumulo iacit Homo ... Rianus fuit._  But the inscription is not _Rianus_ but _Pianus fuit_
column4: as I copied it myself
column5: 1742.''  Later ... Thomas Pennant ... also published the last line as being HOMO PIANUS FVIT ... H. Longueville Jones ... also reads HOMO PIANVSFVIT.

column2: as did Hbner as well as Westwood ...

column1: `... Archdeacon Thomas ... found to his surprise that `instead of the accepted XPIANVS
column2: it appeared to me to be simply PLANVS
column3: whatever the meaning of that word might be''.  This met with `considerable incredulity'' and was only accepted later at the Annual Meeting at Bala in August
column4: when an accurate drawing of the stone was made
column5: showing the letters as they are at present.  There must also have been considerable discussion about this remarkable change in the lettering
column6: but nno details of this are given
column7: only the Archdeacon''s conclusion that `the foot of the L is not any recent addition.  It is of the same smoothness of incision and date as the rest of the letter.''  It was not until 1896 that John Rhys finally got to the site and accepted PLANVS as an original word.

column1: `It is unlikely that Archdeacon Thomas and his fellow Cambrians knew of the drawing of the inscription made by Lhwyd in the late seventeenth century; if they had done they might have come to a different decision.  To accept the letter L in PLANVS had been there always in the past
column2: just as it is today
column3: is to imply that four distinguished antiquaries---Edward Lhwyd
column4: Lewis Morris
column5: Thomas Pennant
column6: and Longueville Jones---were one and all quite incapable of reading a prefectly clearly written inscription in Roman capitals.  I am of the opinion that the documentary evidence makes it certain that the letter I in PIANVS was altered into an L at some date between 1846
column7: when Longueville Jones made his rubbing
column8: and 1884 when Archdeacon Thomas came to look at the stone.

column2: there is not only the documentary evidence to go on
column3: but also the visible evidence of the stone itself.  On this point I asked Mr. J. M. Lewis of the National Museum of Wales to examine the stone with the possibility in mind that the inscrription had been interfered with.  This he has done
column4: and has kindly allowed me to quote his findings.   He considers that there has been some interference with the original inscription at the beginning of the word _planus_
column5: pointing out:

column1: `(1) that this is the only place in the inscription where a space has been left between words;
`(2) that the horizontal line above the P in fact begins above the space to the left

Had the L been part of the original inscription its foot would have been level with the foot of the A

column9: while many of the letters have serifs
