column1: WRHAM|1|1|f|t|some|The surviving letters are clear if of unusual form in some cases.|f|ind|2|n/a|broad|n/a|undecorated|Written along the two stepped surfaces of a reused Roman architrave.|inc|No information.|1|inc||n|rcaps||"RCHAME/1970
column2: 311: `The letters
column3: which vary remarkably in size
column4: are Roman capitals with uncial D and Insular L.  The C is square.  The final letter in the second line is imperfect; it can only be an A with angular cross bar.  The strokes of the C and the Vs are crossed at their junction and several of the letters have prominent forked serifs.

column1: `The closest parallels in Britian are the inscription from Llanfihangel Cwmdu
column2: ascribed to the late 6th or early 7th century [Nash-Williams/1950
column4: and the St. Peter stone at Whithorn
column5: probably of the late 6th or 7th century.  Both show the crossed junctions of the strokes and the variation in size of the letters.  The The forked serifs are used more consistently on the St. Peter stone.

column1: `The forked serif is widely found in Continental inscriptions of the 6th and 7th centuries.  The square C is characteristic of the same period in Gaulish inscriptions.  The uncial D does not occur in the earliest group of Welsh inscriptions
column2: dating from the 5th to the 7th centuries
column3: though it is found in group II
column4: _e.g._ at Llanlleonfel [Nash-Williams/1950
column5: no. 62].  The insular L at Llanddewi Brefi may be rather earlier [ibid. no. 116]
column6: but the form is characteristic of group II
column7: from the 7th to the 9th century.''"|WRHAM/1/1

column2: 188--89: `The lettering on one side of the stone is in good condition
column3: except that the lower part of the second line is chipped away
column4: and the lines are imperfect at the sinister end.'|f|ind|2|n/a|shaft|n/a|undecorated|The inscription occurs to one side of the middle-band of the pillar but as we do not know the orientation of the stone when used for the inscription it is difficult to assess its original layout.  Comparison to other stones might suggest the test ran vertically down in which case it occurs below the band.|inc||1|latin||n|mixed||"RCHAME/1970
column5: 311: `The regularly formed letters are mixed Roman capital and Insular forms.  The U is angular
column6: almost square.  If the reading of the fifth letter in the first line is correct
column7: the uncial and Insular forms of the letter appear side by side; the concurrent use of two forms is common in Insular majiscule MSS.  The last letter in the line is incomplete
column8: with only the rounded back remaining; a capital E of rounded form is likely.  The reconstruction of the base of the letters FIL at the beginning of the second line is conjectural; no trace of the second I of this word remains.  A few of the letters have forked serifs [cf. WRHAM/1/1].  Both the D and the Q show a slight shallowing of the groove
column9: almost a gap
column10: between the upright and the loop; this feature may be compared with the treatment of the cross arms in a number of Welsh crosses
column11: which there is reason to attribute to the 7th century.

column1: `The closest parallel in Insular epigraphy is the rather later inscription at Llanlleonfel which should belong linguistically to the later 8th century [Nash-Williams/1950
column2: no. 62].  Both inscriptions have the same tendency to square letter-forms; both use the Insular N
column3: the Q with a loop and long shaft
column4: and the square U.  But Lllanlleonfel uses the uncial D while Wareham prefers the Insular form.  The tendency to separate the different parts of the same letter may also be noted at Llanlleonfel.  In Insular epigraphy the forked serif occurs occasionally as late as the early 9th century
column5: _e.g._ on the Caldey Island stone [Nash-Williams/1950
column6: no. 301]. In Wales the square U is found in the latest inscriptions of group I (5th--7th centuries); the Insular N is first used in group II (7th--9th centuries).''"|WRHAM/2/1

column2: 188: `The inscription ... so far as it remains
column3: is in good condition except for a few slight fractures.'|f|ind|2| inc|broad|n/a|undecorated|The inscription covers the whole of one face of the stone
column4: presumed to be the broad face.|inc||1|latin|"RCHAME/1970
column5: 311--312: `The second word in the first line [C...] may have been adjectival or a noun in apposition... The C which follows [the first name] cannot of course be interpreted; it is possibly the first letter of some adjectival epithet.  The punctuation point seems to prevent [it] being part of the name.''

column1: For further linguistic discussion see ''Name'' notes.  "|y|rbook|0|"Macalister/1949
column2: 188: `The A is inverted : the second T was originally written G and then clumsily corrected ; a _vice versa_ interpretation is also possible
column3: though slightly less in accordance with appearences.  LIUS is presumably the end of FILIUS
column4: but although there are about two inches of space vacant before the L
column5: there is no trace of the missing letters.  Its seems that the curve below the fourth letter
column6: which turns the T into a G
column7: has been interpreted as an abbreviation for the missing NIS of a gentive GIDEONIS
column8: but this is hardly admissible.''

column2: 311: `The letters are irregular and straggling.  The forms are generally insular majuscule
column3: though the A and U and the rounded E are better described as debased Roman capitals.  The A in particular is anomalous; it appears to be a reversed example of the capital type with angular cross bar (_cf._ No. i [WRHAM/1/1]).  The fourth letter in the first line looks as though the workman first cut a T
column4: repeating the previous letter
column5: and then corrected to G.  The last letter in this line could be O
column6: but this is unlikely.  The first four letters in the second line are cramped
column7: as though the cutter began FI]LI.GIDEO and later inserted the US.  The central bar of the rounded E is separate from the rest of the letter (_cf._ No. ii [WRHAM/2/1]).  There are traces of forked serifs....

column1: ` Some of the insular forms used in this inscription are found sporadically in the latest Welsh inscriptions of group I
column2: dating from the 5th to 7th century.  Their more consistent use in this inscription indicates a date after these forms had become established.  Welsh inscriptions of this period are not common and it is difficult to suggest a close parallel.  The use of stops to separate the words has no chronological significance.''"|WRHAM/3/1
189: `... imperfect : what remains is in good condition''.
308: `imperfect at each end.''"|f|ind|2|W|shaft|n/a|undecorated|RCAHME/1970
column3: 308: `cut along the damaged drum of a column'.|inc|||inc||n|rbook||"Macalister/1949
column4: 189: `The lettering ... has ornamental serifs''.

column2: 312: `The letters
column3: which are straggling and disparate
column4: shew a mixture of Roman capitals and Insular forms.  There is no trace of the initial D.  Two forms of capital E are used in the first name.  The last surviving letter in the first line is probably FI ligatured
column5: as the end of the cross bar is beginning to drop; the upright of the F projects above the looped upper bar.  The first mark in the second line is the tail of an oblique stroke; it is difficult to explain this except as the end of an uncial A
column6: a form used occasionally in Insular Majuscule MSS.
column7: or an Insular R together with the more normal letter.  The beginning of an A can also be distinguished at the end of this line
column8: much disguised by  the surface abrasion of the stone.  Forked serifs occur on a number of letters
column9: but there is no consistent use of them.  The words are separated by stops (_cf._ No. iii [WRHAM/3/1])."|WRHAM/4/1

column2: 188: `The inscription is in good order ... one letter is damaged.  The surface is thickly covered with whitewash.''

312: `A fracture almost obliterates the fourth letter and damages the fifth.  The small centraln fragment has been slightly displaced so that the fifth letter reads badly.''"|f|ind|1|W|broad|n/a|undecorated||inc||1|name||n|rbook||"RCAHME/1970
column3: 312: `The letters are Insular majuscule with a Roman capital E.  The N is adapted from the uncial form
column4: which is used in some Insular MSS. together with the more normal N.  Several of the letters are characterised by an extension to the left of the tops of the uprights; this feature is particularly noticeable in the N
column5: where the tops of both uprights are so treated.

column1: `Letters of the same general character are found in the 8th-century inscription at Towyn
column2: though the forms are there less exaggerated and the setting out more irregular.  The forked serif to the central bar of the E is uncertain as the surface is here abraded.''"|WRHAM/5/1

column1: WRXTR|1|1|f|f|good|There is some surface damage to the text
column2: and a little of the right hand edge has been lost
column3: but it appears legible with only two letters (third line
column4: L and N) noted as questionable by Wright (Wright/Jackson/1968).|f|horz|3|n/a|broad|n/a|moulding|The inscription is cut into a raised moulding which probably formed a border on the original Roman monument which was trimmed down.|pocked|Wright/Jackson/1968
column5: 297: `[the] three lines of lettering had been pecked in the manner of quarry inscriptions'.|1|inc|Wright/Jackson/1968
column6: 299--300: `The name _Cunorix_ preserves the final _x_
column7: which makes it unlikely that the iinscription can be later than the loss of certain final consonants
column8: including _x_
column9: which is an early aspect of the loss or shortening of some final syllables about 500.  The Latinized _macus_ for late Primitive Irish _*maqqas_ from older _*maqqos_ would seem to show the change of _q_ to _k_ before a back vowel
column10: and _Maqui_ the preservation of _q_ before a front vowel.  Hitherto there has been reason to think the former took place in or by the first half of the sixth century
column11: whereas before a front vowel _q_ may not have become _k_ until towards the end of that century
column12: a distinction which is quite natural phonetically and is strikingly paralleled in the history of Vulgar Latin.  Lastly _Coline_
column13: which is on the face of it an error for _Colini_
column14: calls for two linguistic comments.  First
column15: it does not yet show the vowel change which would have been expected to turn it into Culini at some time in the later part of the fifth century; and second
column16: it has _-e_ for _-i_.  If this last is not simply a mistake
column17: it may be that at about this time final long vowels unprotected by a final consonant were already beginning to becone shortened and indistinct
column18: a development which is a forerunner of the total loss of certain final syllables about 500 mentioned above; and the local engraver employed
column19: not an Irishman and not knowing the language but hearing Cunorix's heirs say something like _kol'in'I_
column20: took this last sound for an _e_
column21: as a speaker of Latin naturally would
column22: and therefore used E
column23: probably thinking the form was a feminine genitive of the Latin first declension if he thought about it at all.'|n|rcaps|-1|Wright/Jackson/1968
column24: 299: `Epigraphically
column25: the lettering is crude Roman monumental capitals
column27: not chisel-cut
column28: markedly different from the `official' Roman inscriptions of the Empire period
column31: belonging most probably to the year 407
column32: is a (very untypical) `official' inscription which is not at all unlike it.  In fact
column33: the lettering of the Wroxeter stone is indistinguishable from that of the earliest series of post-Roman `inscriptiones Christianae' of the West
column34: dated by Nash-Williams between the first half of the fifth century and the middle of the sixth
column35: before the intrusion of any uncial forms.  That the Cunorix inscription could well be as late as the early part of the sixth century
column37: is shown by Nash-Williams's nos. 104 (Justinus securely dated 540)
column40: perhaps about the same date).  Thus epigraphic considerations alone would allow a date somewhere between the beginning of the fifth century and the middle of the sixth.'|WRXTR/1/1

column4: 65: `The first letter D is reversed

column9: to agree with the next word FILIUS
column10: in which the F and I are conjoined
column11: both the L''s with the first stroke obliquely slanting
column12: the terminal s reversed and of the capital form: the third letter of the second line
column13: which I had regarded as L
column14: disagrees with the two L''s in the preceding word
column15: and agrees with the last letter s in the first line; the following letter
column16: which I had considered as a prostrate I
column17: notwithstanding the short unconnected vertical stroke
column18: is most probably a reversed T
column19: as suggested by Prof Rhys; the next character is a prostrate I (completing the word IVSTI)''.
